description:
The day after I got engaged, my fiancé took me here for lunch.
Everything was so good especially the cacao drink which became my favorite.
I'm definitely coming back for more
author: Nichole F.

description:
Of the 3 Nicaraguan restaurants in the Mission, this is the longest hike from the BART.  It also seems a tad pricier than the rest.  Food is pretty tasty, though I believe Las Tinajas Restaurant is my favorite in the neighborhood.

Especial María Elena: So much delicious food!  The charbroiled steak had nice sear marks and a little redness inside, so was just right.  The pork had a very pink marinade going on and was also charbroiled just right.  Neither strip of meat seemed overly spiced, but the pickled onion salsa on the side did a wonderful job of livening them up.  The rice & beans, sweet plantains and plantain chips were pretty standard and quite plentiful.  Not a huge fan of all the shredded cabbage, but that's more of a personal preference.  Loved the two chunks of fried cheese, definitely something I look forward to in Nicaraguan cuisine.
author: Adam B.

description:
Great food good service. It was my first time here and we had a large group which was easily accommodated. The cabbage hot stuff is awesome! We shared the beef and pork plate #27 and it was enough for us both and we are big eaters. 

Another pair shared the beef plate #26 looked awesome and they ate most of it. Another person had pork plate couldn't finish and she was very happy.  Another had the chicken and she could not finish and left happy. 


Reasonable prices great food, my only knock is it is kinda dirty looking and there were flys in restaurant. Will go again but probably take out. 

Oh yeah try the tamarind juice it is awesome!!!!
author: Paul D.

description:
Horrible service!!! They  got both orders incorrect and the food tasted far from the original Nicaraguan food.

The waiter looked like a gang member out of jail with no customer service skills. The food was more expensive then regular Mexican food with lower quality.!

Don't make the same mistake I made. Don't go there.
author: San R.

description: Not a bad spot. They are pretty busy for a really small for a restaurant. They have a lot of customers so about 80% of the time your missing something or they didn't hear your complete order. A bit  frustrating especially when you wait 45 min to and 1 hr to get a table, then another 30 min for food. I would base the food off the pictures post here and not the menu, it comes out really different. Beside that enjoy the serves smile and the music played during dinner on weekends.
author: Miguel P.

description: Genuinely amazing place!!! My only complain is that their queso frito was not like the one in Nicaragua (this one's a little smaller). Other than that. Truly spectacular food! Best place for any Nicaraguan missing home! El filete estaba DIVINO!
author: A S.

description: Came in, seated, spent a gooood while b4 the menu was made available, then took another healthy break b4 the food showed up, being from Nicaragua I believe I know my food...
author: Rigoberto C.

description:
I rarely write reviews but when I do, it must have been something that really bugged me or impressed me. In this case, I'm just surprised. First off, I'm giving them 2 stars because my dish was good. Their customer SERVICE sucks! Waitresses are rude and clearly do not enjoy their job just the paycheck. They would rather "clean" then serve their customers. Who ever the owner is, you should retrain them or hire friendlier people.

My mother ordered a soup and her fish tasted sour to her. Waitress took it back and said "nothing is wrong with it" and offered another dish. Ok, so she reordered. Maybe 15 mins after waiting for the second dish I stood up to ask about dessert and a box for my leftovers. Well she rudely assumed I was questioning about where was the food. It was just poor service!
author: Gloria E N.

description: Very clean food, price are great, a lot of choices, this Nicaraguan restaurant is a good place where to have a good food time in family or by yourself.
author: Eduardo S.

description: My husband is Nicaraguan and likes this place for their Cacao (drink). I'm not a huge fan of Central American food but this place is so so. What is most important to know is that it takes at least an hour to get your food after you order it. We're going to look for better Nicaraguan food restaurants as this one is not worth the long wait. Only reason to come is to get a jug of cacao to go.
author: Liz R.

description: This isn't my cuisine. Dry meats and overall bleh. I did like the live music, but the venue is much too small for dancing. Additionally, if you're not Latino, you'll be really out of place.
author: Paulina F.

description: Given that there are only three Nicaraguan restaurants in SF. This by far is the best one! It has a great atmosphere and the food is fantastic! They have some amazing variety. The portions are huge (except for the Baho, i few like they could totally improve there!) The traditional fruit drinks from Nicaragua are also great. The place is cash only, which is all right, but they could change that. I'd go back every time though.
author: Ed H.

description: Gallo Pinto was amazing, tostones amazing, everything super delicious. :) So glad I found this place!
author: M R.

description:
Sad to say this place has gone downhill fast. 
My husband ordered the cacao drink which was more water and powder more than anything. The calala was delicious and very authentic. I ordered the arroz avalenciana which was ok but lacked flavor and overly greasy. The salad thatvwas served with my plate looked like the lunch salad they would serve back whenni was in high school.  Disgusting. My husband ordered the 7 mares and it was more grease in it that soup, it was literally dark brown. The quality of food has completely downhill.
author: Yamilette C.

description:
I was happy to find a nicaragüense food restaurant on a Sunday afternoon still open:)
The food was really good I'd give it a 5 star the services was ok I'm sure our waitress was tired seemed like she was doing everything on her own 
But the 6 o'clock man who came in to sing made the experience unpleasant!
I wanted to enjoy my meal with the juke box music they had previously but I ate my food very fast to just get out once he started singing!
author: Maria S.

description:
Rude! My friends and I wanted to get tamales for people we were visiting to go. Every employee eye on us was cold and unwelcoming. By the looks on their face, the waitresses felt they were too good to serve us. When we got to the counter, the waitress told us, " I don't THINK we have tamales." When we saw her just serve another customer that..

And here's the worst part. I'm guessing this is the owner because he was an older man and had a suit on. He put his hands on my waist and shoulders to talk to me. I don't care how "friendly" you are trying to be, never touch a stranger, especially when we have shit service like that.

Save your money and go somewhere else. No matter how young or old the person looks, never treat your customers with such disrespect.
author: Sami N.

description: I have been here several times with my family. The food is good and pretty traditional. The service needs some work, looks like there needs to be perhaps one more server during peak times. The wait can be someone long at times, but ultimately worth the wait. Gallo pinto is great and the pork is nice and tender. I love their vinegar spice onion mix they leave on the tables. It's nice to have a traditional Nicaraguan restaurant to visit.
author: MJ L.

description: Oh my God I'm so disappointed with this place I went for lunch with my daughter and to take food to my grandmother at the Jewish care living center in San Francisco and I bought sebada and one chicha and I had to return mine the chicha it was rancid then I took my grandmother the sebada mind you she's in an old folks home and weak . I got a call later that night they found her on the floor in the bathroom covered pink throw up . The took her to the emergency and now she swallowed some of that rancid throw up and had and infection . This place will seriously be hearing from our lawyer this is wrong they could have killed my grandmother the whole family from all parts of California having to drive to see what they think is their mothers on her death bed . She's still very sick ( reason I haven't contacted them or the lawyer yet is she still in the hospital . .They will be screwed when I get the paperwork that shows she ate nothing except for that sebada
author: Tanya H.

description:
I must admit one thing before I begin my review... I am accustomed to the " finer " things in life.  Good food, good drink, fast cars, fast women... :)  all those things come naturally to me.  Being the first-born son of a scion of a well-known " Somocista " family will do that to you.  I have visited my lovely Nicaragua 9 times in my life and I have seen and experienced pretty much all there is to do in my lovely country, but the pleasures of the flesh ( specifically, the food, drink and female kind ;) are what keeps me coming back there for more every time before I have to hop on a plane and come back to the dreaded " USA ".  
     So what does a hoighty-toighty Nicaraguan expat do when he wants to eat a fine Nicaraguan meal when he is NOT at home, in Nicaragua?  He seeks out the finest place in his area to eat a fine Nicaraguan meal, and for the longest time I could safely say and surmise that the place to go in the San Francisco Bay Area for Nicaraguan food was Oye! Managua in the Bernal Heights district of San Francisco.  They had their stuff down COLD, I mean, the BEST Nicaraguan food you could possibly have within hundreds of miles of California's vast and varied terrain, I mean, you would have to go to, I guess, Los Angeles to get a meal better than the meal you would get at Oye! Managua.  Sadly to say, the past two times I have been there I have been SORELY disappointed with the quality of the food.  It has diminished considerably.
     My Mother ( who was my Valentine's " date " this year ) and usually get the Maria Elena plate, which is the most colassal plate on the menu, consisting of the best Nicaraguan " street food ", the kind you would get in the " parillas " and " fritangas " of Nicaragua, and on this plate you find:  gallo pinto ( Nicaragua's own concoction of mixed rice and red beans, VERY tasty ), fried Nicaraguan cheese, plantain chips ( plantain is a fruit like a banana ), ensalada ( salad ), carne asada ( grilled skirt steak ), chancho asado ( grilled pork ), and maduros ( ripe fried plantains ).  All of this is an ENORMOUS meal fit enough for 2 or 3 people and is a pleasure to behold and eat, and I took the liberty of taking pictures of the meal to show what it looks like.  Sadly, it didn't taste NEARLY as good as it looked.
     It was HEAVILY doused in cooking oil all around!  I mean, greasy, oily, and nasty cooking oil taste all over, from the steak to the chips to the rice and beans, I mean, EVERYWHERE!  The steak was overcooked, fatty, and overseasoned.  The fried cheese was very good, as was the fried pork ( the highlight of the meal, you could taste the marinated lime, lemon, and other goodies used to marinate the pork in ) but the rest of the meal was SEVERELY lacking.  I would tack this to a bad experience but this happened the last time around too, so I believe they must have a new cook or something who does not know how to properly cook Nicaraguan street food!
     I think I will have to book the first red-eye to Managua the next time I want to eat my beloved " fritangas " :(...
author: Gonzalo O.

description: Ordered the Maria Elena plate to share and both me and my friend woke up at 4am with food poisoning. Never again.
author: Santa H.

description:
Filete a la plan ha con camarones-- grilled and seasoned to perfection. 
Very authentic Nicaragua restaurant at the end of Mission.
author: Nicole S.

description: Avoid this place like the plague. Ever since they changed ownership this place has gone to hell in a basket. The food is ok but the service OMG, rude for days. The staff is so unprofessional and they close the Restaurant at any given time for any bogus reason. Never again!!
author: Tony S.

description:
My girlfriend returned from Nicaragua a week ago and she was craving some of the cuisine so we checked this place out and it did not disappoint! Very simple ingredients but extremely tasty! Also, the portions are HUGE so they're definitely splitable between two people. I came in starving and left stuffed.

We had the Maria Elena plate. Highly recommended!

Also, I don't know why people say the service is bad...All of the wait staff were very attentive throughout.
author: Zachary M.

description: The food was great. Authentic food from Nicaragua  and the Toña  was the best.  The only thing when it was time to pay the girl said cash only, and said there was a sign outside the door saying cash only. I looked outside and no sign is at the door. I disliked that if it's a restaurant cards should be accepted. I saw other people with cards. Rip off. Only 3 star rating.
author: Mercy T.

description: Food is OK, but the service makes this place worse. The ladies there always have a stank face, it never fails. Super rude. You're better off at Las Tinajas! No longer spending my money here, apparently it's not good enough. DO NOT COME HERE.
author: Crystal C.

description: A great sampling of Nicaraguan food. Not as good as my grandmother's but pretty close.
author: Cesar A.

description: This is the spot for authentic Nicaraguan food everything is cooked fresh the atmosphere is beautiful authentic naca-tamales!! The VERY BEST
author: Lyn W.

description:
Okay all you Latin lovers, brace yourselves. Now I'm always down with some Nicaraguan food, but this place is not the place to go if you're looking for good service. I attempted eye contact with the waiter. No luck. I waved my hand for the waitress. Still, no luck. I got up and did a little dance, and that definitely got some attention, but not by any of the waiters or waitresses. Aye yi yi!

I ordered the pescado empanizado and it tasted as if it was frozen and then flash fried. So not the business. I left more than half of the fish on my plate. Whomp, whomp. BUT I got to give it to Oye Managua for pulling in the customers. This place looks like its got its regulars, so something is working well in that respect.
author: Flor K.

description: Oh by the way, my friend saw a rat running in the kitchen. I told her she needs to report this to the health dept. So nope....won't be going there ever again!
author: Iris M.

description: The food is good overall and they have really big dishes. The bandeja nicaraguense es gigante!
author: Jonatan A.

description: The food was good, but the service it's always horrible and if you ask for the receive the got mad at you, and wait another half and hour to someone  just give you same order they have from the kitchen... Not good place to spend your money when they treat you very bad... I used to like this place before, but lately it's not worth the drive from east bay ;-(
author: Vanessa D.

description: Very good meal. Satisfying. What more can I say? It's pretty authentic. I'm happy with it the moment I walked in.
author: King L.

description: I still enjoyed my pork meal but I don't think I would  back. It doesn't feel like a restaurant because I think the owners or workers need notions of service, presentation and restraint service in general. Also, it felt awkward that the post says just cash and then the cashier accepts card, when I was about to pay, the other guy said no credit cards. Anyways, they accepted it. Something good: the food
author: Victorya Esmeralda L.

description:
I'm afraid I'm going to mangle the name of the dish I had. It's on their printed menu at their restaurant but not on their online menu. And it's totally delicious. Filete de pescado entomate (?) entomade (?) arrgh I give up! Fish steak in stewed tomatoes basically. So flavorful and the fish was so tender. Comes with rice and whole beans (choice of separate or mixed together), a small slab of fried cheese, and plantain chips (choice of that and something else that I couldn't hear - not a language barrier but it was Sunday and they had a live singer doing Latin pop, just a heads up - but the chips were good as well. The rice and beans (which I got mixed) were a bit on the salty side, but soaked up the broth from the fish dish nicely. Anyway, I was quite full and happy.

I think a lot of their customers are regulars as the place was quite full and parties would come in and hug the staff or otherwise greet them more than a simple hi. With dishes like this, no wonder they have a lot of regulars. I need to become one.

No language barrier for English speakers (as long as the music isn't too loud, which would present a similar problem for me in any restaurant). If you need it quiet, probably go during the week.
author: Charles B.

description: Your restaurant has great food but your staff especially ladies no manners not a hello goodbye come again thank you nothing. Not professional at all no manners  you need to hire people that will welcome you smile and have manners.This is why waitress didn't get a tip from us. Usually we're great tippers.
author: Patricia A.

description: Los nacatamales más sabrosos de la bahía, also the best fritanga in town, my recommendation will be Maria Elena good for two if you have a humongous appetite. Again NACATAMALES !!!! Are yo die for
author: Z. C.

description:
Very good experience. We were headed towards "El Buen Comer" but when we saw the "too polished" appearance of the restaurant decided to go back and have dinner here.

Ordered the Maria Elena's special and was full of meat and rice, I especially liked the fried cheese.

Service was pretty neutral, no fake smiles but no rudeness either. Prices reasonable.

The ambience was interesting, a guy "on stage" sang a lot of different Central and South American songs - cumbia, salsa, etc etc.
author: Xavier R.

description: There is not enough words for this place.  It's one of my favorite Nicaraguan spots in the Bay Area.  They give HUGE PORTIONS, the food is always fresh and the service is great.  It's a small restaurant, but they always do their best to accommodate you.  It's worth any wait!! Every plate I have had there is delicious!
author: Kristin R.

description:
Best Nicaraguan restaurant in SF.
Great portions. Great ambiance.
Music, laughter, family friendly, and warm.

Easy to get to via car or public transportation.

Across from Safeway on 30th and Mission.

A few blocks from Mitchell's Ice Cream.

Next to a laundromat.

Street parking.
author: Angela B.

description: I'd never eaten Nicaraguan food before, so coming in I didn't quite know what to expect, but this place was really good. We came for a late breakfast on a Tuesday and it wasn't very crowded.  We each ordered a plate with gallo pinto (so amazingly good), two eggs over easy (it comes with scrambled eggs), fried plantains and fried cheese. I really, really enjoyed everything on the plate. The gallo pinto was so flavorful and the egg yolks and salsa mixed in was to die for! Scrambled eggs wouldn't have had the same effect. The fried plantains were almost exactly how I like them: crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. My only complaint is I wish they were sliced thinner. Service was fine and they let us order breakfast even though we were 15 minutes after 12 (thanks Kaiser :-p).  I would come again in a heartbeat.
author: Steph L.

description: Absolutely love this place! A must dine in place for me everytime I'm in the San Francisco area!  Definitely authentic as it gets!
author: Chris F.

description: Food is good!!! But waitress had a horrible mad FACE. You asked for something she gave you this look; like I mean It was my first time there I asked and she just said if I wasn't ready to let her know when I was ready to order. We asked for an extra side of chicken nuggets and she said she couldn't sell it to me unless it was a meal. So I said fine charge me as a meal but give me another order of chicken nuggets, she said if you don't want the fries even though you pay for the whole meal I can't give it to you! Like what???!! She need customer service skills
author: Daly R.

description: So, a friend convinced me to join her for lunch on a Saturday afternoon to eat here, of course, I had no expectation of anything good coming out of this place but quite frankly, I was taken by surprised. The service was good, and the food great. My friend got the beef soup, I had a nacatamal, a side of sweet fried plantains and a cacao.  When she brought out the plantains I only got three, I said, where's the rest of my order?  She went back to the kitchen an brought out 4 more.  I think it's a hit or miss type of place.  But the food was good. It seemed like the kitchen has changed for the better. Thank goodness!
author: Petra M.

description: 01/12/2017 @ 5:57pm.   So I'm writing this minutes after I saw a mouse ran across the the restaurant. This is so disgusting. I couldn't even finish my food. The lady gave me a free beer for the inconvenience and said that she saw it too and that the next building over is fixing the pipes on their bulding which is why there was a mouse in here. THIS IS CRAZY! Never coming back. I loved this restaurant too. Smh.
author: Vanessa G.

description: I am Nicaraguan and used to love going to this restaurant and loved the food and service.I been going to this restaurant since it first opened and  own by the original owner ,which also is owned El Red balloon restaurant on 24th and Mission Street. Back then food was real Nicaraguan quality, the new owners food is not the same. The son of the new owners is a waiter and makes mistakes  on taking the orders, when your food arrives you get a totally different thing then what you order. When letting him know that the order was incorrect he started to argue with me saying that he took the order correctly and I was wrong. I guess he expected for me to keep the food that he brought out because it took him a while to take the plate. When grabbing the plate and about to walk away in a low tone voice he said"YEAH WHATEVER" !. Didn't even show any "respect" for the customer to say "I'm sorry" sir I will fix this for you and bring you the correct order. I will never in my life dine at this restaurant ever again. I have never received this type of "BAD" service anywhere as I did in this place.VERY RUDE!!!!.
author: Robert C.

description:
Food so good that it made me fantasize about a trip to Nicaragua.

We opted for the Especial Maria Elena ($28) since the trio of ladies next to us seemed to know what they were doing. Come hungry since the platter is enormous and includes gallo pinto, rice, cerdo asado, carne asado, tajadas maduras (plantain varietal), fried cheese, and some kind of aspirational salad.

The cacao drink was cinnamon and vanilla and honestly was like the best choco milk. 

The Tona beer was nothing special, but I think the point is how refreshing it is. Great summer brew!
author: Kevin L.

description: probably the best Nicaraguan food in San Francisco. sadly there isn't much competition in this category, but that's not why Oye gets five stars. it gets five stars for the Maria Elena, a monstrous platter of all the classic Nica food whose flavors will instantly whisk your mind and soul away to a true Managuan fritanga. and yes, it's cash only. who cares? middlemen are thieves.
author: Ronny K.

description: Ok, so I ordered the chicken and chicken Meat balls soup and I only got as far as Meat in my soup .....one small chicken wing and one small chicken Meat Ball! And it the was almost $15 for that soup. What a rip off!!! Beware!!!!
author: Bernadette F.

description: The food is just as good as my mom's cooking. I just got back from Nicaragua a week ago and can say the food here is really authentic. I ordered the carne asada plate and I got a healthy portion of Fresh Gallo pinto, crispy tajadas verdes, a little salad, and perfectly seasoned carne  asada. I was happy.
author: Karla g.

description: We had the Baho (under the especialidades section of the menu) and it was just delicious!  The brisket was super tender and very flavorful, the platanos were great, and I have never had yucca with such good texture and flavor.  Every bite was a win.  Huge portion for $14, it was enough for two of us.  Great value, good music / atmosphere, friendly and not pushy service.  Highly recommend!
author: Oren F.

description:
The food was so.. delicious and that's coming from a guy that lives in Los Angeles and pretty much had  visited all the nicaraguan restaurant in L.A county. 
Every time I come up to the bay area oye managua  will be one of my stop. 
Don't take my word for it,  go try it for your self
author: Marvin M.

description:
Ok... I really had to think about how many stars this place deserves..

My husband's friend who was born and raised in Nicaragua brought us here yesterday for lunch, and up until yesterday, I had never tried Nicaraguan food, so I was super excited. I love trying new food! And what better what to do it than with a friend who knows what it's about!! 
So we parked, and headed into the restaurant around 1:00pm, and the first thing I noticed was that it was CASH ONLY. I hate cash only, but I guess no biggy, our friend went to the ATM next door. The place was busy, but we were able to sit down immediately, and were given our menus. 45 MINUTES LATER the waitress took our order!! That is no joke! I'm not exaggerating. From the time we sat down, our order was taken 45 minutes after. She never even came over to acknowledge us. Our friend had to call her over twice. The first time he did, she very rudely told him to wait. If it weren't for our friend taking us here and loving this place because it feels like home, I would've said something after 15 minutes, but I let it go. After ordering, it took another 30-45 minutes to get our food. What irritated the hell out of me was that two tables that sat down about 10 minutes after we did got their food about 20 minutes before we did. I hate it when restaurants do that! My 1 year old is fantastic when we go out to eat, but even this was too long for her, she was getting pretty fussy. 
Our friend ordered two plates of the Maria Elena Special, a side of the fried cheese, and 3 cacao drinks and man was the food awesome! I loved it!! He originally wanted to order just one of the Maria Elena Specials and then another, but the waitress told us that they were out of the other one. I didn't hear what he ordered, but I thought it was strange that they were out on a Sunday for lunch (probably their busiest time of the week). You should have popular items prepared.. just saying.. but anywho, the fried cheese was so good!! My husband really liked the asados and plantains, and my daughter loved the gallo pinto. Either that, or she was starving from the wait -___-. The salad also paired really nicely with everything else. I loved everything! The disappointing part... the waitress never brought the side of the fried cheese. Unfortunately, my friend never double-checked it, but I really hope he wasn't charged for it because I felt like he was. The crazy part was when she brought the two plates of the Maria Elena, she said the fried cheese was coming, so I don't know how it got lost there..

We left a 3:20pm. We were there for lunch over 2 hours!! 2 HOURS!!!!! I'm just glad that we were with good company. Chatting helped distract us from the RIDICULOUS SLOW SERVICE. And to me, the waitress wasn't all that friendly or apologetic about the long wait. I actually thought she was rude. I am so happy our friend took us here, but it sucks how bad the service was. I really wanted to give it a 5 star review because the food here is awesome. So awesome that even after the experience, I think I would come back, but I definitely don't think it deserved it. I actually think I'm being generous with the 3 stars..I think if this place were to do better in serving their customers it would be a HIT! Because so many people already love this place and talk it up. I just hope next time, service isn't as bad. I guess I'll have to see.
author: Kristina S.

description: Mexican style ice cream and fruit not sure what else they had. Person are counter spoke little English so I had difficulty ordering but good stuff if your looking for a spicy sweet cool treat
author: Gineeta L.

description:
I'm 100% NICOYA and I know this is good atmosphere and good food just like everyone says, I love going there with my wife eat have a Tona, but bad service lately. I always used to order Maria Elena and had them give me chancho frito rather than chancho asado and all of the sudden they don't do that anymore? wow!! if you go to a restaurant and your order onion rings rather than fries, I think is the same, RIGHT?
as you walk in the sing say "CASH ONLY" well that's FALSE I have seen them taking credit cards I guess people that they know or they like. TIPICO NICARAGUENSE,SIEMPRE DE LADRONES Y HACERNOS VER MAL A TODOS LOS OTROS NICAS. This place is going down hill and I DON'T think will be going back. DISAPPOINTMENT. any suggestion where to eat COMIDA NICA??
author: Hermes M.

description:
Best place for nicaraguense food! 

The plates are pretty decent and food taste like authentic nicaraguense. 

Keep in mind if your looking for a fancy place, over the top prices and you will be judging customer service.Then this is not the place for you!!

Pros: awesome food
Cons: Only cash, seating is tight
author: Carol M.

description:
If there were a no start, I will put it. 
I am very disappointed and sad. This was first and last time I go to a Nicaraguan restaurant in the most famous city in the world San Francisco. It is a shame to see that every restaurant I have visit convine me every time that my money is more worthy that throw it by going to this restaurant. 
I just left this place and it was not pack but the service and food horrible. I went with my family carving howtown food and I left there  wishing never have gotten there. I ordered a green plantain plate  which was ok. My son ordered the fried prawn Nicaraguan style supposetly but believe me it was nothing like I have eaten in Nicaragua. It looks like they took it for Costco big bags and just reheated them and no special sauce. I was shock when I saw it. And my husband order a 7 ocean soup which never came and we ended it canceled right when it was about to come to the table but we were sooo frustrated that it never came and the others plates were cold of waiting for that soup to come. I must said it had nothing to be with  waitress. She was nice but the kitchen was the problem. They obvious don't know how to get a whole table ticket out. Well, the worst place to go. Don't recommend at all.
author: Milly L.

description: Nicaraguen food is delicious here. The portions are filling. Even tho it gets crowded at times it's worth the wait. The meals are hearty and a must try. On Sunday's they have live band playing. Pretty cultural and live. I really enjoyed it here.
author: Ivania B.

description: Worst experience ever. Sat night a lame singer that was too loud. I'm with 11 people grandmother mother father kids. The family ask multiple times to turn it down. When I approached him to turn it Dow the staff told me if I don't like it leave, and I left, NEVER to return. Horrible.
author: Tweeb K.

description: Went here to celebrate new year's with my boyfriend's family and it was the top google results for Nicaraguan food! My boyfriend and I shared the Especial Maria Elena and their food is so delicious! Although it was crowded and we had wait for a table, we didn't mind because the food was worth it. Got introduced to Milca (red soda) by my boyfriend's family and I love it so much! Overall great experience and service was good too :)
author: Adrienne C.

description: Es un Exelente restaurants. We love it!!! It's OYE FABULOUS.... ... We always have the best time with family and friends... Toñas are the best to the best OYE FABULOUS....
author: Anniuska G.

description:
Why oh why have I waited 20 years to eat at Oye Managua? I live in the neighborhood and was remiss in not eating here before. 

I LOVE LOVE LOVE this restaurant and have been just twice now and can't wait to go again. It's always a good sign when you crave the food from a restaurant! 

So far I've had: Especial Maria Elena (Gallo Pinto, Cerdo Asado, Carne Asado, Tajadas Maduros Y Verdes, Fried Cheese, Salad) and Tajadas Maduras O Verdes Y Queso (Plantains with Cheese). Both dishes were great! 

Get on down to Bernal Heights for a great Nicaraguan meal!
author: Yvette K.

description: I'm Nicaraguense, but don't speak Spanish and I don't know if no one works here that doesn't speak English or if I just have the worst luck. The food is delicious and I try to come atleast twice a month (I live in San Jose,ca) and will take a drive out to SF when the craving is to intense. Point blank, food is great, atmosphere is great, just wish they had some English speaking waiters/waitresses to make things easier. 4 stars for language barrier
author: Fallon O.

description: Great food. Good costumer service except for they honestly do NOT know how to use a calculator, (or they were just trying to rob us). We split the check three different ways and every single check was added terribly. One check they added $20 extra. The second they added $45 and the last and worst one they added over $110!!!! It all seemed so unreal after we recounted all checks four times. But they changed the price with no problem. Besides that, good service and great food. I just recommend that you add up the check yourself so you won't be paying extra money. They deserve the four stars because we were a big party and they got (almost) all of our orders right. But whenever we brought up a problem with a dish, they fixed the problem right away.
author: Julio V.

description:
WORST EXPERIENCE IN A RESTAURANT. And why I post a review until now.  I don't write reviews on people behaving uncivilized but this one keeps bothering  me cause I was present with friends when it took place. A physical fight like one of those that you expect in a low class bar. This one was between (2) mature "ladies".  One was drinking by the "so call bar" and the other one a "walking customer". Based on the accounts of incident, all these ppl new each others and these "ladies" had some ongoing issues which one of them decided to take care of that late afternoon. The owner/supervisor didn't do anything to stop the fight, it seemed like they were relatives, police were not called , no apologize given to customers, we did not even started our meals but I got billed for it. 
The worst experience a customer could have.
author: Maddy J.

description: Food was on point but unfortunately the service was just so bad.... Now reading other reviews guess that is to be expected... It was hard to get attention, ask where my food was, and why would you serve a crab soup with full crab legs if you aren't going.also have a cracker so I can actually eat it. Just a spontatenous solo lunch on my birthday before the eve and it the service made me legit sad.
author: Kate R.

description: This restaurant is my favorite restaurant...especially when I'm craving Nicaraguan food. Their food is always delicious. I always order the tilapia jalapeño Nicaraguan style. I love it!!! But, you should always ask if they have it in stock before you order because sometimes they do not have it. Other than that, I always order their cacao... omg this drink is the best. The customer service is fast and great. They always check up on you to make sure you are doing okay, if you don't know what to get on the menu they help suggest some things to get and it all turns out so yummy. I can here alone once when I first found out about this place. Then I came with friends. And then my boyfriend m, and lastly with my siblings. And all the impressions I got from all of them was Wow! This is good!!  So I would highly suggest coming here if you are definitely in the area.
author: Rhoddavie M.

description: If your looking for good Nica food this Is the place! We ordered the Maria Elena plate is was more than enough for two. Beef pork Gallo pinto platanos queso  everything was DELICIOUS. MY 1ST timr trying milca  a Nicaraguan soda  Mmmmm so tasty I will definitely  be going back!
author: Nicole G.

description:
My family and I visited here and it was an interesting experience.  Besides it being ridiculously hot that day we needed to bring our patience here.

We walked in and realized they are cash only so had to go to the Safeway across the street to get money. Once we got back we sat but waited forever to be served menus.. I mean a long time, my husband had to go ask for them and an employee just pointed to where they are .
Then after that we were finally helped and the food was decent.  My husband had the Vigoron with cacao and I had the Nicatamal with a Toño. Very yummy!

I'd come back but make sure you have cash and patience
author: Alecia S.

description: Food was ok. The service was terrible!!!! My daughter asked for water, the waitress brought her tap water with no ice. Waitress never checked on us. When it was time to pay the bill she was over charging us by $10 dollars. If you go here make sure to check your bill... Not a good experience!!!!!!
author: Sarela Q.

description: Excellent authentic Nicaraguan food. "Especial Maria Elena" was amazing and perfect for two people to share (we even had left overs). Chia drink was delicious and refreshing. Live music was great and added to the experience. Highly recommend and I will definitely be back.
author: Carlos R.

description: Went to this hole in the wall on Mission and I was in Nicaraguan foodie heaven; better than what Abuelita makes. It's a small restaurant and crowded but the service was fast and servers were friendly. My family shared a nacatamal, Nicaraguan tamale. It had a ton of pork, not too spicy and the masa was yummy. I had the #31 which is Gallo Pinto, moist yet crispy fried pork, plantains, a traditional cabbage salad, and a piece of fried cheese, paired with super sweet Milca Red Soda. My only complaint, not enough fried cheese and not having enough room to try more.  Recommend to all Nicoyas and anyone wanting to try Nicaraguan cuisine. Will be coming back!
author: Andrea M.

description:
I am neither Latino nor Nicaraguan. I think I understand the attitude remarks. It did feel a little like, "what are you doing here? Your in a restaurant of an ethnicity different than your own... Be flexible or stay home.
We had the Maria Elena, sopa de raiz, green fried and dried fried plantains, rice and beans. The plantains were sweet and ripe, the meats tender and well seasoned. My chia drink was sweet and cold. I liked the casual family friendly vibe.
author: Susangela M.

description: It was very hot the night we were in and there is no AC. While we only had a couple of beers while waiting for the Japanese place next door to open, the food looked incredible and we did recommend it to a couple who has traveled to Nicaragua and they seemed very pleased with their meal. The place was packed with regulars. I can't wait to go back on a cooler night and take it all in. I fear that throwbacks like this in the neighborhood are soon to be a thing of the past.
author: Brian B.

description:
Good food. They take a little time but it was worth it,  authentic Nicaraguan cosina,
Recommend the. Bajo
author: Nelson C.

description: I love coming here cause the carne asada with gallo pinto and queso frito and  fried plantains are so fricken bomb!!!! But the price is so expensive where I can just ask my moms boyfriend to make it but she's in LA. For the amount they give you is pretty good. I got the cacao as well and it's so fricken good. I love nica food!
author: Micah G.

description: I am Nicaragüense, my family's from Managua and this is my Death-Row last meal! I've been coming here for over 10 years. Aside from my family's recipies, this is the closest thing to authentic Nicoyan food. Carne Asada, gallo pinto, platanos (fried sweet bananas) ensalada with subtle lemon juice, platains (banana chips) and gueso frito. For those who are unfamiliar with Central American cuisine, 2 words "gueso frito." Fried cheese. Need I say more!? Mouth-Savoring bliss.
author: Tybalt X.

description: Who cares about decor and service when the food is ON POINT!  Just show up, order and shut-up.  It's the best in the bay! When I crave Nicaraguan food and my grandma is not around to make me some, I head on over to Oye Managua! Parking is actually easy. Just bring change or bank card for meter.  Enjoy!
author: Mrs. M.

description: Very bad customer service, when you ask the waitress for something they ignore you or take a long time to do it. Mu muy mal servicio al cliente. Las meseras se hacen las locas para no atender bien. Como que uno les piden la comida gratis si uno esta pagando por los servicios!!
author: Glenda R.

description: I'm Nicaraguan and I love this place!!! It's a little on the pricier side. But, it's pretty authentic and the vibe is totally like it would be in a Latin restaurant! Their nacatamles are bomb and bistek encebellado is super yummy too!
author: Cupcake 1.

description:
3.5 STARS

I think weekends are a good excuse to be, act, and look like a bum. 

Come Sunday afternoon, I made an executive decision: I ain't cooking so we're going out to brunch.

I walked out to the living room in a ponytail, no makeup, no eyebrows (thanks to a botched Chinatown eyebrow tattoo job when I was 16), a faded t-shirt, stretchy yoga pants, a fleece, and tennis shoes. 

Me: "Ok, let's go."

Mr. NSS *chuckles*: "I thought we're going to brunch...are we going running instead?"

Me: "Uhhh, when's the last time you've seen me run?" 

*Awkward silence*

Mr. NSS: "You're normally so put together...today, you look kinda...ummm..."

Me: "The honeymoon is OVER sweetheart so you better get use this look."

Mr. NSS: "You still look great!"

Me *rolls eyes*: "You're a whoreable liar...let's go."

We both never had Nicaraguan food before (shame on me) so decided to check out Oye! Managua since it was nearby. Everyone stared at us when we walked in and we were the only non-natives there which is always a good sign at any ethnic joint. The ambiance is very vibrant and cheezy (http://bit.ly/TvzSsQ). Not a good date place, fellas; well, not if you want to get lucky that is. If you're a carniwhore, you will be in meat heaven at Oye! Managua as the majority of the menu is very meat-centric.

In true Yelp fashion, we over-ordered and ordered for a family of four. The portions at Oye! Managua are no joke so beware. 

Craving something soupy, we ordered the Mondongo ($10), a beef tripe soup that's served with white rice and corn tortillas (http://bit.ly/TvzwTb). I'm huge fan of Mexican menudo but not the Mondongo. The tripe was very chewy and needed to be cooked down more while the soup base was too sour for me. The Lengua En Salsa ($13) totally redeemed the Mondongo. Huge chunks of lengua were stewed in a flavorful tomato and onion sauce until it was uber tender (http://bit.ly/Yh98RI).This was served alongside white rice, beans, plantains, fried cheese, salad and corn tortillas. I would come back for this dish alone. And then the Nicaraguan behemoth arrived...the Caballo Bayo ($26). HOLY F*CK, this thing was HUGE (http://bit.ly/UzIz4J)! Enough for a family of four, the Caballo Bayo (wrong description listed on menu) consisted of fried pork, shredded beef in the same tomato and onion sauce as the lengua, chicharrón, Nicaraguan sausage, gallo pinto (rice & beans), fried cheese, fried plantains, and corn tortillas. This dish was more quantity than quality as the fried pork was dry, the chicharron so hard it can chip a tooth, and the plantains were over-caramelized causing a slight burnt taste. The tender shredded beef and sausage were good texture wise but that's it. The best part of the behemoth carniwhore platter? The gallo pinto and the fried cheese! Yup, you read right. The rice and beans were so robust in seasoning (cooked in meat broth?) that it was absolutely addicting. The fried cheese was crisp with a soft, oooey gooey center--simply irresistible.  

Barely making a dent in our meal, we walked out with 3 full boxes of food to bring home. I also walked out with an 8 month old food baby. SEE, I knew wearing stretchy pants to brunch would come in handy. 

Fellas, never second guess a women's decision. The End.
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Boom!!!! on point the caballo bayo they way they make it is off the hook..... other places make it diffrent but i dont mind thier way at all...la sopa de mondongo is tripe soup im a fan of menudo so i can dig this alot.... they serve good fresh nicoya food it takes alittle bit to get your food but its all good for me ill wait alttle bitno worries.... i also get the especial de la casa its a combo alittle bit of everything thats what i get after a nice hang over lol.. with a tona beer yea im cravin one right now. service is alittle slow they really dont check up on u... you have to wave them down alot of the time thats a little wack but i dont mind it..... the parking sucks too hahaha but eventually youll find one
author: Rigoberto C.

description: the gallo pinto was delicious (3.5-4 stars). this place was packed one sunday afternoon as we were lunching, but got a table right away. My fish was unimpressive (2.5 stars), okay that was kinda a gamble. But my platanos maduros? they weren't ripe enough they were all hard and weird, fail (1 star). No reason to return anytime soon. Fun atmosphere tho, nice servers.
author: Coco J.

description:
The 1 star is because I had to give them one. Otherwise it would have been NONE. ZERO STARS. NASTY PLACE.
WORST PLACE TO EAT. the food was cold, the service BAD. I been told this is a great place. It was packed when we went. We found a table right away and sat. Our waiter didn't acknowledge us until some other customers sat behind us, and were given menus and attention first. Right away I knew this was not going to be a good experience and I was right. We order a churasco, and antojitos nicas. Thank God I kept a menu. The food was not brought at the same time. A different table was served first before my food arrive even though my friend had her food already. When asked where my food was, the waiter looked at me like I was crazy. 2 different tables were served before my food came. My food was COLD, and it was missing 2 items. I had the antojitos nica, no sour cream or chicken. Instead of chicken I got chicharon  (not the same thing) when I told the waiter they were 2 item missing all he said was "ok"  he brought the sour cream but kept on waiting for the chicken. I ate my meal, but I was discussed by it. The pork was hard and cold, Platanos cold and oily, the sausage burned out and cold, the queso frito cold. The Gallo pinto was the only decent thing, as well as the tacos. When I asked the waiter again where the chicken was, he responded  "they ran out of chicken, that's why you got chicharon" I told him "if you knew they ran out of chicken, why didn't you tell me I could have order something else" he didn't respond. We asked for our bill, of course it tooked for ever to get the bill, when he finally brought the bill, he brought me 4 pieces of chicken wings, and guess what? Yep they were COLD too. I took a bite out of one and hot outside and cold inside. I spitted out right away. SAVE YOUR MONEY, DON'T GO THERE. Loud music, bad service, and cash only. I DIDN'T TIP THEM, was not going to waste any more money there. 
Sad this place is Nicaraguan food. I'm a proud nica, but this food was NASTY. NEVER GOING BACK. LIKE I SAY, BAD FOOD AND SERVICE.  EAT SOMEWHERE ELSE PLEASE.
author: Sophia E.

description:
I've given this place so many opportunities to prove me wrong. I've come here a few times and the food is decent (nothing special) but today the food was awful again! 
Also the service sucks! I explained to the owner that I didn't think the employees had good customer skills she apologized. However today, she was the waitress and the service was terrible! It was 10am they just opened but she just seemed completely upset about being there, she did not seem happy to be there. Food was disgusting! Gave me a huge tummy ache! Just to think that the owners are giving horrible treatment that means it's the worst. I'm never going here again. With service like this, nobody will show up anymore ....
author: Vera M.

description:
I love this place. When I lived in Oakland, I would travel to the Mission about once a month for lunch at Oye Managua. Nicaraguan food is hard to find on the west coast outside of SF or LA, but the mission has three (or four; one is half Salvadorean). I ate at all of them before I traveled to Nicaragua and easily Oye Managua is the best. I only wish that they would serve Guapote. The food compares to the Nicaraguan traditional breakfast food served in Nica itself. The service is courteous and friendly-even to gringos with only an intermediate level of Spanish (or less). I felt like Oye Managua helped satisfy my craving for Nica cuisine after coming home.

Get the Gallo Pinto, the price can't be beat. The Maduro is excellent. I didnt like the queso, but having tried it elsewhere and in Granada, NI it is just too strong for me so it is not fair for me to judge. Nactamals are pretty good as well. Gallo Pinto is the best though.
author: Bryce H.

description: Oye Managua has the distinction of not just having some of the best Nicaraguan dishes in one of the best locations in the Mission district, it is also the only place where the ambience feels as if you were in Nicaragua itself.  The best dish by far is their Carne Asada, but it's one of the few places that will serve the traditional Red Snapper with the Nicaraguan tomato sauce that many coastal regions are known for.  There are some caveats, like the difficulty in finding parking and the fact that the place is popular, therefore will be busy during dining hours and weekends.  Nevertheless, it is Nicaragua outside Nicaragua.
author: Luigi D.

description: This place isn't anything special. Food was okay but not a big wow. Service was horrible though. We got seated, got our drinks, and then they moved us to another table. Not only that but it took forever to order, to get your food, to pay and then to get your change back. There were only two waitresses for the entire place. Seemed like we were there forever just waiting and the waitresses weren't friendly either.
author: Amelia C.

description:
This is our family spot.  We have being going with our family since 2006.  The Mariaelena plate for 25$ is so worth it.  Makes me hubby feel like he is back home!  My first experience with Nicoya food and I am sure glad.  From the old owners to the New we feel like family.  Thank you Oye Managua. Cant forget the amazing and talent on Saturdays...godbless you guys.

Jose and Johnnett Moreno & family
author: Johnnett T. Moreno M.

description: This is by far one of my top three favorite restaurants. The meal I always get is Carne Asada and Cacao. Best food ever. One thing that I didn't like was that the last time I came here with my boyfriend and his parents, (they are white and dont speak spanish) our server didnt really understand english that well, so it was difficult to get our orders and we were kind of scared to get the wrong orders. But either way they thought the food was great and I thought the food was great and that's all that matters. Definitely recommend to anyone and everyone!
author: Jullissa S.

description:
Best Nicaraguan food by far! You may not like it if you are a "health aficionado"
The decor is not "acceptable" by North American standards. But I go for the food and the friendly atmosphere. If you are worried about calories... Maybe not your place. I love it!
author: Edgar T.

description: Really delicious food and great service plus music  make a really great Sunday dinner !
author: Rosa P.

description: Love this place!! Definitely authentic food, just like in Nicaragua. However, if you're American and have a standard for good service, you might not like it here. Hospitality is not their best virtue. This venue is tiny and hard to get a table on a busy night. The servers are not friendly... Their only concern is getting the food to your table. Just keep that in mind, and enjoy the food!! I recommend the seafood soup (siete mares), or the sampler "Maria Elena" will give you a taste of everything Nica (carne, gallo pinto, tejadas fritas, queso frito). But my all time favorite dish is the Indio Viejo, which is a meat stew. The nacatamal here is also really good, and less fatty than what you get in Nicaragua.
author: Amy P.

description: Worst place to order food. I ordered 13 Nacatamales a wk in advance and when I called to pick them up they said they had no order. Wth? I was saddened because they were for Xmas and pissed because the woman I spoke to did not offer any resolution and was rude. I will NEVER go here and I will tell all my friends and family the same.
author: Lizette V.

description:
My friend has his birthday dinner here, and with about 20 of us there in a small restaurant it was still nice. 
The food was very good. On point. I got the #21 chicken with rice, beans, fried cheese and salad. the portions are very generous. 
They also have a guy playing the piano and singing Latin music. Parking is tricky since Mission is so busy. but I'd def come back here.
author: Irma R.

description: The food there is great best Nicaraguan restaurant I been to  the people there is friendly music is on point  the owner is always smiling very good customer service it's a very friendly place to go to  they also have.  the best cacao ever to
author: Ligia L.

description:
I recently had a meeting in the area and decided to meet some friends at Oye Managua, Nicaraguan food we always crave, I have not been there in a while, but I always like the food and the cold Toña beer. 

After a couple beers, we decided to have some "boquitas" something to munch on, we did not know what to eat, we asked the friendly waiter Hector and he suggested some steamed yucca with fried cheese ad a cole slow type salad, it was very good. 

One of my friend order a 7 mares soup, (seven seas) a mix of sea food soup. Well, it was delicious, the taste was so good that you can think you were at the beach. We enjoyed the rest of the food. 

The service was great, Hector keep coming by and asking us if we needed anything else. The owner Gaby came to say hello and she reminded us to come by on friday for live music. The place has changed the paintings, no more old dolphins are not there anymore, it fits better with the area and the food still great. 

I definitely recommend it to my friend, it's worth the visit anytime.
author: Carlos S.

description: Picked up some food today. Different from what I usually order. Nacatamales and bunuelos are great. Ordered the churassco today, it was over cooked and hard like rubber. Not worth 17.00. Not too happy today.
author: MariaFer D.

description:
Went here with a few friends for dinner as it was rated fairly highly on Yelp, and when is Yelp wrong? Now. This place should not even be above a 2-star. 

The decorations confused me and made me feel like I was in a demented horror house - you will know if you go here what I'm talking about. 

There was a man playing an organ and singing with a massive amplifier for place with maybe a dozen tables. This allowed me to not be able to speak to the people next to me. He did have a great voice however. 

A table in the back were celebrating a birthday, to which the cook from the back came out banging on soapy pots and screaming like a banshee. Very odd. At least they clean their dishes. 

The food? Well, if what you want to order is salt, then this place is for you. We ordered and split their largest platter to share, which was fried, yet uncooked cheese, a 4lb heaping pile of the saltiest and least flavorful beans and rice I have ever had (how do you screw this up?) and a few slices of overly charred (and did I mention, salty) meat of some unknown origin. Thinking this wouldn't be enough, we ordered a tamale. Unlike a more traditional approach of wrapping in a corn husk, this was wrapped in saran wrap and wax paper. Interesting touch. Odd consistency. 

Overall, I would not recommend this restaurant unless you are in a large group of Nicaraguan buddies looking for a dance party and salty treats on your birthday.
author: Anthony G.

description: I was honestly impressed! This food made me feel like I was back in Nicaragua. Everything tasted amazing and made to perfection! I will definitely be coming back! Only downside was I wish the restaurant was a bit bigger and wasn't on a cash only basis. Nonetheless the food is always delicious and fresh, portions are pretty big and they have a large selection.
author: Katherine S.

description: Really good food! Authentic and delicious. The servers were super friendly.. Even desert was amazing. I will be back!!
author: April B.

description: Really good food but knocked off 2 stars for service and decor . We walked in and waited 5 minutes to sit even though we made eye contact with the waitress several times . She was pretty rude and looked extremely unhappy to be there. Reading other reviews I felt like everyone was talking about our same waitress . The food was delicious however , so that made up for it . Decor was horrible , demented Latina horror house best describes it
author: Lauren A.

description:
Love this food.
Aside from Las Tinajas this place is really good. I am Nicaraguan, so I know my food...this place is really good when your not in the mood to cook it yourself.
They have good portions, decent prices and on weekends, they have a guy who plays music.
Typical Latin spot, where people are laughing and talking super loud. So if that's not your style, then maybe pick a diff spot.

I haven't tried the indio viejo, but it didn't look appealing to me. I usually go for the good ol' steak with gallopinto. the bajo is also really good.
author: francis c.

description: Great comfort food for a cool SF day. The fried pork was crispy and full of flavor, but the real star, (and this is a first for me to say) was the rice and beans, which seemed to have little pieces if pork in them.  I couldn't get enough! The plantains were also very good. The service was pleasant. The place can get a bit crowded, so if you've got a stroller, like us, be polite and maneuver carefully. Also, they have a sign that says "cash only", but I could sworn I saw people pay with cards. Either way, there's an ATM across the street at the Walgreen's.
author: Kris Marie D.

description: I am Nicaraguan and the ambiance is VERY Nicaraguan. That being said, the food is hit or miss; the vigoron was good and so were the tajadas but the nacatamal was subpar. It was good to satisfy my craving but didn't blow me away.
author: Christine A.

description: My husband and I went there for some appetizer. We sat and order.The waiter afte he took the order came to tell us if we can sit and another table   because the one we were sat was reserved.  We felt very un respectfully.  From the restaurant in charge nt to le us know since the begining. We never going back there
author: Yamilette C.

description: Food is excellent and better priced than La Tinajas. The wait times for a table can be long. Service is okay - could be better.
author: Gabriela G.

description:
When ever I'm in the City I have to go into the Mission District and get some Nicaraguan food.  My parents were from there and past away over 20 years ago.  
On this trip after two wonderful meals based on my yelp friends reviews I had to do my pilgrimage into the MD and have some old fashion Central American Food. 

I went for the Caballo Bayo, a huge amount of food but it is like a sample platter. 

Fried Pork crispy outside tender inside light marinade 
Shredded Beef in a light tomato sauce with onions and green peppers
Sausage Nica style 
Chicaron pork rind
Gallo Pinto rice & beans 
Fried cheese
Fried plantains, corn tortillas
Maduro ripe sweet plantain 
Wonderful cabbage, tomato in a vinegar mix
 And a Tona a Nicaraguan Lager Beer to was it all down.  


 If  you are a first timer you can go for the Baho
A brisket slow cooked in bananas leaves served with rice, yucca , plantains both non ripe and ripe, along with cabbage salad y tortillas.  A delicious tender pece of meat nothing very exotic.  But all the dishes are very good, fish, chicken pork or beef.  

Good eats
author: JORGE R.

description: I will give it two stars because our fish fillet in Jalapeno sauce was good. However the service was terrible. My two year old was really hungry and every, I mean every restaurant understand that you have to bring out the kids food 1st. We had order chicken nuggets with french fries. The chicken nuggets were from a package and so were the fries. So my question is why take forever if you get them from a bag already prep and you just have to reheat. My was was upset because when we got everything, all the food was cold and she mention something strange, she said why does not smell like food? whenever you go to a restaurant you can smell from the dining room they are cooking something in the kitchen but you don't smell nothing at all in this place. mmmmmm strange.
author: Milton M.

description: I've always heard people talking about this restaurant and how good it is.  I finally came and tried it out and what can I say, the food is appetizing and fulfilling.  The SERVICE in the other hand, is HORRIBLE!  Since we got there we received an ugly look from the waitress and from there on it just continued.  I had to ask them three times for a refill!! I ended up having to go to the counter and asking for it again, and on top of that they charge $4.50 for a tiny kids apple juice (same prices as a beer).  Doubt I'll be coming back here.
author: Katy P.

description:
With some of my fiance's Nicaraguan family in town, it was time for a feast at Oye Managua.

The Especial Maria Elena is not messing around.  That Maria Elena knows what's up - a giant platter filled with carne asado, cerdo asado (grilled pork), gallo pinto (Nicaraguan fried rice and beans), fried plantains, plantain chips, queso frito (straight up FRIED CHEESE), and a hint of vegetable in the form of two dollops of salad.  My fiance and I ended up splitting it because he convinced me it could feed three and when we finished we looked at each other and were like ehhhhh I could eat more. 

Unfortunately what the Maria Elena delivered in quantity it did not live up to in quality.  All the sides were good (I could probably eat gallo pinto forever), but the pork was so dry and tasteless we thought it was chicken breast.  Definitely not a compliment.  The carne asado was slightly overcooked as well.
author: Cathy Y.

description: We were the only one in the restaurant and it took 45minutes to get our food and the girl who served us was very rude when we requested a refill of water
author: DUN UP B.

description: Cash Only. Other than that if you crave authentic Nicaraguan food,this is your place.
author: Jeanine M.

description: Foods great, service sucks! Super unprofessional. Called for an order for pick up an hour ago and get here they don't even know who took the order. Then they take more than 30 minutes to bring out the food. Are you serious? Never coming here again.
author: Nubia L.

description: Nacatamales are a classic Nica meal.  I have tried them at Óye Managua twice before and have not been satisfied.  Thinking maybe the cook had an off day and jonesing for some hometime flavors, I tried it again today.  Again I was dissapointed.  The masa was three to one on the meat and flavorless.  While I realize they are the only Nica restaurant in this part of town (due to the sad closing of Nicaragua Restaurant and La Carne Asada), I also realize they are short-changing us on flavor and quality.  Oye Managua, stop peeing on my leg and telling me it's raining.  I am from Nicaragua and know what a good nacatamal is supposed to be like--flavorful masa with a good meat to masa ratio.  Nevermind that there was only 1 thin slice of potato and the 1 thin slice of tomato were negligible.  ¿Qué les pasa?  ¿Á quien creen qué engañan, a los cheles?  No vuelvo a comprar nacatamales alli.
author: Maria M.

description: Great food, horrible service- little over 2 hours at the restaurant, the waitress never came to check on us....  still had to get up and get my bill.. if I ask for boxes to go is not to stare at them for 15 extra minutes.  I expect to get the bill when I ask for it...
author: Maira B.

description:
"Survivor Nicaragua", I thank you for leading me here, even if the entire meal was on my cordoba - er - dime.

At the onset of each new season of "Survivor", NJ and I divvy up the contestants.  Loser (always me) owes the winner a meal, hopefully at a place with some relevance to the underlying season.  I tell you, finding a relevant location for Survivor Vanuatu  was tough, even in San Francisco!  No such problem with Nicaragua.  

NJ and I headed out to the far reaches of Mission Street, bound for "Oye! Managua" (gotta love a place with an exclamation point in the title).  There's a  million places that look similar out there, but we were happy to see that Oye! was about 90% full with families and couples.  

At the recomemndation of yelper Gonzalo, NJ and I shared a Maria Elena platter ($25 and enough food for 2) and a nacatamal ($5).  I also sucked down a satisfyingly sweet, cold, cacao ($3) which was something like a mix between horchata and cinammon-flavored choclate milk.  

The Maria Elena, easily the most expensive thing on the menu was more than ample food for the two of us.  At $5, the nacatamal (big, Nicaraguan tamale, presented beautifully) would actually have satisfyingly served one of us.  The Maria Elena + the nacatamal meant both a) doggie bag needed and b) no room for dessert.

The Maria Elena platter includes:

- Nicely sized slabs of grilled Carne Asada and grilled Pork
- Yucca and deliciously sweet Plantains 
- Cabbage salad, a perfect complement to the meats 
- Fried cheese
- all served atop a heaping volume of a black beans, rice, and onions.  

Everything was VERY good and VERY filling.  I especially liked it all mixed up with the spicy-onion tabletop condiment.  

What I wasn't expecting, but really loved was the live music, the old man boogieing in the back, and all of the table-approaching vendors (most of whom I think worked there) hawking CDs, candies, pastries, roses, and bedazzled t-shirts which would self identify me as a "SEXY NICA".  Sexy Nica or not, Oye! is definitely worth checking out.
author: Tracey A.

description: The worst part of being Latino... Not speaking Spanish.  Haha, nevertheless, the authentic food and service ease your stomach into a full food coma.  Let's be honest, Latin food will never look visually appealing but don't let this intimate you from its savoriness taste.  Many people may recognize the Latin drink called horchata; however, Nicaraguans have their own take on it called cacao.  It's blended better than a typical horchata drink but similar in taste.  Give it a try.  I visited this location during lunch hours which was perfect because there were plenty of seats to choose from inside tables to window seats.  Plenty of meat options, so don't forget to add cheese on EVERYTHING!!!  Give your taste buds a change from the typical American cuisine and stop on in.
author: David W.

description: This place used to be good back in the days but now a days, the food an service went down hill completely!  The last time I went, I sat down for about 35 mins before they gave me a menu, then another 30mins to come by and take my order and to bring my food other another 40mins. Just terrible... The waitress even had the nerve to say,"Oh I didn't know you came here to order food" Ummm lady, what do you go to a restaurant for? Anywho... Since that terrible experience, I decided I would never go back. I heard they changed owners, so that may explain why the food doesn't taste the same anymore and the service sucks! The only good thing there is the music.
author: Patty S.

description: This place used to be good went a few days ago and service was horrible. Took forever to bring our drinks, as well as to take our order, as well as bringing out our food. On top of that they gave one of us a wrong plate that did not belong. And tried charging us for exrra things that we did not order . . The waitress was not.nice at all seemed like she she did not care at all for her tables. Felt like we were there for too long waiting on everything. Wth oye managua !  Que es lo que te sucede !?!?!?!
author: Josephine L.

description:
Walking into this place was like walking into my grandmother's house.

The decor was tacky but the food was BOMB. 

Ok, so my grandma is Salvadorian, but I lived in Managua for 3 months so I have a sense of what Nicaraguan food is like outside the United States. 

The older man who greeted us was super sweet and reminded me of a grandfather type figure. He was one of the friendliest people I've encountered in a restaurant in a while. 

I was in a rush and starving so all I had was the gallo pinto. I remember having gallo pinto every freakin' day when I was in Managua, so this was a nostalgia pick. 

The gallo pinto was just like the type I had in nicaragua. Tasty. 

I want to go back and see how the nacatamales are or the pitaya juice. 

It seemed a bit on the pricy side for Nicaraguan food, but I'll see how it is relative to the quality of the food next time I visit. 

With latin-american food I almost always disregard decor and service....it's all about the food.
author: Carlos A.

description: I heard this place changed ownership.  I used to go here with family for birthdays and get together.  It was good authentic Nicaraguan food.  I had a craving for some Gallo Pinto today and ordered to go. The lady I ordered from seemed bothered and quite unfriendly.  I work in customer service and I am attentive and always happy to help others.  I didn't feel that today.
author: Roger O.

description:
I am quite jealous seeing everyone's great reviews because yesterday I had my FIRST and LAST experience here.

Was craving Nicoya food so decided to yelp a place and saw that Oye Managua had great reviews, so decided to check it out. 

Came here with my BF and we both ordered the same thing, steak with onions (don't know what the name is). Waited and waited and the waitress finally came out..

(FIRST MESS UP)
She brought BOTH of us the wrong plate. I sent mine back but my bf didn't want to be an ass so he was stuck with this disgusting shredded meat plate.. yuck. 

(SECOND MESS UP) 
When the waitress came back with the right plate, I took a bite into the steak and it was soooooooo TOUGH and OVERCOOKED! (I don't know if that's the way that it's supposed to be cooked but the waitress didn't bother to ask how I wanted my steak...)  My bf told me to give it to the dogs because that's how they like it (yes it was THAT tough!)

(THIRD MESS UP)
As I was signing the check, the waitress came to me and said that I was signing the wrong one.. mind you I had already written $0 tip on it and signed it. I was like ok, whatever.. so then I go to sign the other one and look up and the waitress is STILL STANDING there, looking at me and waiting for me to sign the check! WHO DOES THAT?! In the end, I ended up giving her a $2 tip because of the fact that she was standing over me... I really didn't want to give her anything.

Overall, the best thing on my plate was the fried bananas.. loved those. The beans and fried cheese were good too but the other things like the steak, onions, rice and salad could have been made at home.. and made even better than they make it here. But they have this spicy onion sauce on the tables which is pretty good.. I could've eaten that by itself! Anywhoo, both of these plates were $13 each which is really steep for a place like this in the Mission.. it's not even comparable to Cha Cha Cha's or Esperpento! This place was VERY disappointing and if I ever do try Nicoya food again, I will be going to Las Tinajas!
author: Sarah E.

description: I've had Nicaraguense food before and I'm seriously in love with it! Our go to spot closes early and my family and I were craving it, so we decided to go here. The food has a really good taste the only reason this place is getting two stars. The service.... Oh my. TERRIBLE. But I always say "there goes your tip" I don't expect to get my butt kissed but decent service and not arguing with the customer would be nice. To start off, she kept rushing us to order all at the same time, some of us showed up first and the other half like 15 min later but she said "if you all don't order now you won't eat together at the same time" like jeez lady let us breathe. First off, they couldn't get orders right because they kept bringing us things that we didn't order!!! I don't understand how you mix orders up with other customers, very unorganized if you ask me. My aunt ordered something and we thought they had brought her the wrong order... So we let the lady know, she came with the menu trying to argue saying "no you ordered this" in the end she was right, it was the rice she got mixed up. But the attitude she came out with was insane, we told her we didn't want that plate in the end but she rudely said "sorry we can't change it because it's cooked" excuse me? We didn't touch or eat it, anywhere we've gone they have changed our order when we told her that she literally walked away with out saying a word. It's also pretty pricey but whatever... All I'm saying is that a smile and better attitude would've bumped this place to 4 stars.
author: Vanessa S.

description: If I could do no stars I would! The worst service ever! I always come here and will never come here ever again! We sat down, not seated down. 3 people came in after us, and they were seated and they took their order and us nothing! I had to get up and ask them. They got our order and then all the other people were being served and we hadn't even had water. The other people left and we still hadn't got our food. I'm just in disbelief!
author: Karen A.

description: Food was pretty good, but that was about it. Service was bad, got the wrong beer and when I asked for the one I ordered I got an eye roll. Someone at our table ordered coffee when we sat down because she was cold and wanted to warm up. After 20 minutes I went to tell our server we didn't want it and she said it's coming, like it was no big deal that so much time had passed since we ordered it. Everyone else got their drinks pretty quickly. We were a party of seven. Three people got their meals, then about 10 minutes later two more got their meals, then about 5-7 minutes later the last two got our food. It was horrible timing. Oh and when the bill came we were informed they only take cash. No ATM in the place either, and no signs stating that they do not take cards. Just not a good experience over all. Wouldn't go back.
author: Sandy C.

description: Service is mediocre.  But food is not that bad .   Live entertainment . Parking is kinda hard to find but u can risk parking at safeway ( not my fault if u get towed).  Nicaragua is not known for customer service .  Nicaragua is the most vulgar spanish speaking country  in all of latin america .  So sorry for your bad service" hijo de la gran puta!"
author: Joe B.

description:
3.5 STARS

My first time having Nicoya food. 

Thumbs up to:  Ramon the owner who is absolutely wonderful and accomodating!  Portion size (esp. Maria Helena platter)!  Gallo pinto for the starch!  Virago which are basically BOMB Chicaronis!  TONIA BEER & CACOA for drinks! Plantain Chips!

This place is small however can accommodate a few bigger groups (8-10 people).  Its 2 blocks away from Mitchell's Ice Creamery where you can venture off to for dessert.
author: Deanna A.

description: I wish I could give this place a review but considering that the only two times I have actually walked in & taken a table I have never really be attended. Today was my last day visiting that place. When you walk in the vibe is so happy & the music makes you feel at home. But when you see that none of the waitresses are smiling or acknowledging that someone has just walk in & bother to take a menu to the table just kicks you right out!!!
author: Allison M.

description: The food is good, but they need to work with the servers, they rush you and have really bad attitude to us, the customers. There aren't enough menus for the maximum  capacity of people
author: Aaron B.

description: Usually I wait a few times to write a review BUT here I am.  We went on a Friday evening (we being my wife and 22 m.o. son). It was packed but the servers were nice and found us a table.  The food was delicious (fried plantains and beans/rice were excellent, as was the lengua) and there was even a DJ.  It did run a tad on the loud side though.  We will certainly be back.
author: Jan N.

description: soooo good! highly recommended true nicaraguan restaurant...i always get the chancho (pork) asado with gallo pinto and plantains with the cacao drink. you can thank me later :)
author: jason xavier c.

description:
This was our first visit to this restaurant and we loved it!!  The food was excellent, the service was great, the food was delivered quickly, the portions are big and the prices are very reasonable, plus we really enjoyed the ambience and the music.  We met Gabriela, the Owner, she's really nice and friendly, we 're definitely coming back!
Excelente servicio, la comida  es deliciosa, las porciones son grandes y los precios muy razonables, conocimos a Gabriela, la duena, fue muy atenta y amigable.  Definitivamente regresaremos!!
author: Patty R.

description:
Fantastic food! We had the Maria Elena special and everything was great. It definitely was enough for 2 people. The carne asada was perfect, plantains, fried cheese, pork, everything. 
One totally underrated aspect of the restaurant was the music. The singer was great - I swear it was the radio. Service was also great.
Overall, easily 5 stars. We can't wait to go back and eat there again!
author: Kyle M.

description:
If I could put zero stars that would be the case! Me and my family came here. We had to seat ourselves! We was not 
said hello to. We was not asked what we wanted to drink. We waited and got ignored for 20 mins tell we go up and left. The food looked and smelled good but I will never know. For I am never going back to that place ever again! Worst service ever
author: Brandee D.

description: Absolute disappointment! I am shocked, and appalled by the service I received today. I am not a big time Yelp user, but I had to log in and express what I witnessed today. I have been a customer at Oye Managua many times, and being Nicaraguan myself, I have developed a small relationship with the establishment. However, I will not be returning. We arrived to the restaurant sometime around noon and ordered. The food came out fairly quickly, and after we were finished we asked for our check.
