After four different attempts of asking the waitress, they still would not bring it to our table. After about twenty minutes of waiting, I had lost all my patience  and I approached the counter. I peaked inside the kitchen and I saw a pigeon walking around! The bird was just strolling around the room and the cooks just worked around it! After seeing that , I returned to my seat ( without the check ) and sat there in disbelief. They finally brought our check, and we left in a hurry.
author: Scarlet S.

description: Been disappointed here both times I went. And each time was with my good friend from Nicaragua who had the same opinion--or worse. Everything just tasted wrong. The sauce for my lengua was overly sweet and bland and the lengua not even tender. Gallo Pinto lacked flavor. Tostones were a bit soggy. We have yet to find a Nicaraguan place in SF to compare to the exceptional "LA 27" in Los Angeles.
author: Anthony B.

description: Even though the place is small the have the best nicaraguense god here!! I love it! Its our Sunday ritual! The cacao its DELICIOUS!! I even get one to go for $7 and its a lot of cacao! My baby girl loves this drink!
author: Karina s.

description:
Oye my GOODNESS!!!

Ordered the skirt steak and prawns combo with an additional side of fried cheese.
Skirt steak and prawn combo: 5 stars, the rice and beans were tasty and flavorful, it is not the best cut of steak but the flavor and tenderness of the meat is on point.  The prawns were very fresh and served piping hot...the topper is the fried cheese, fried cheese is all I have to say.

I will not only go back but am looking to make plans right now as to when the next time I can visit.  LEGIT!!!
author: Michael L.

description:
I do not know why this place even has more than 2 stars on yelp. Went here twice. The first time was bad, but I thought maybe they are just having a bad day, so I gave them a second chance. Second time was ever worse...
First of all, the parking is so bad. You have to go around a bunch of times just to get a decent parking. I am not going to lie, the food is good. That's another reason why I gave them another but service sucks. If you don't mind waiting a long time for your food, then it's okay. If you need water, utensils of any help, you have to wait a veeeery long time. And the last thing that I hated about this place is that you cannot go with a big group. The first time the charged us an extra plate. So the second time we made sure to take note of what we ordered, but they did the same thing. They insisted to charge us an extra plate. But I guess that's how they make some extra money. Sorry, but I do not recommend this place at all..
author: Yzabel C.

description: I am a proud Nicaraguan. I am sorry that I could only give you two stars. My husband, my nephew and I had such a disappointing experience the food was not good and that's putting it nicely, very disappointed. They were out of 3 dishes that I wanted my husband to try and the steak was so fat that my nephew wouldn't let me box it up for my husband.
author: Lucia B.

description: The food was good, which is the only reason why they get a star. The service was terrible and that's being nice. My family had reserved the restaurant for a get together after a funeral service and they were expecting a large group. Nonetheless they under staffed and took forever to take the orders and serve the drinks. We were there two hours before the food came. During the wait, the clumsy waitress spills a drink all over my dad with a plate of food that wasn't even for us. So the table is soaked and still no food! I had two kids that ordered chicken nuggets from the kids menu. I am sure they were frozen from Costco but that's what the kids wanted. Yet, they brought the kids food out last. It was ridiculous. By the time their food was out, I had feed my kids from my plate and they were full already. Ugh the worse service ever.
author: Alicia C.

description: The service at this place is horrible. My family and I waited 5 minutes to get the menu, then we waited for another 10 minutes for the waiter to acknowledge us again with a little attitude.  The room was really hot, no AC and no fans. The food is over priced and average at best.
author: Norman C.

description: Called ahead of time to get a table set for my family of 8 - Oye Managua's manager agreed it would be ready. When we arrived a few tables were open. We expected he would combine the tables and seat us.  Instead we watched a total of 5 parties sit down.  When we asked why we were not being accomodated, a female server said, "Seat yourselves wherever."  At this point it was impossible to find ourselves a table together so some of us scattered and waited at the bar and one open table.  My daughter was sitting at the bar and the "manager" spilled BEER all over her.  We asked for a towel and he gave us ONE napkin and no apologies. She was drenched! We left and ate somewhere else. If you like tiny dirty restaurants and rude unprofessional people to serve you, go to this sorry joint.
author: Nancy F.

description:
Oye Managua used to be a good place to eat the delicious food of Nicaragua. However, when the new owners came into the picture, everything changed. The food became plain and way overpriced. I do NOT eat there anymore.

If you want good Nica food, I suggest you go to Las Tinajas. It's the best nicaragüense restaurant in the city. The prices are definitely worth it and everything tastes fresh, unlike at Oye Managua.
author: Dee U.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in the CITY! I love their carne asada plate....SOOOOO GOOD! It is a HUGE plate too! My wife and I love this place so whenever we crave carne asada and we have a huge appetite we will go to Oye Managua. 

Prices to me are higher than expected but worth the price!
author: Justin W.

description:
1st time to this Nicaraguan Restaurant. Pleasantly surprised at how good the food was. The portions are very large so easily shared or can be lunch for the next day. 
Waitress so nice and attentive.

I ordered my gold standard when eating Nicaraguan food. Salpicon(chopped boiled and then pan fried beef with green peppers and onions), gallo pinto (black beans and rice), tajadas verdes (green plantains thinly sliced and fried) and fried cheese (queso Frito).
In addition the Cacao (a drink where the cocoa bean is roasted then blended into milk), I must say, blew the competition's out of the water!
I think I found my new favorite Nica place to eat.
Oh, oh and I must say it is cheaper that the competition in terms of portion to dollar ratio.
Cheers!
author: Maurice A.

description: I love my Oye Mangaua rest! food is always hot and fresh and service is great! They are doing a great job!
author: Melvin B.

description: Delicious food... Miss my home food. I had the salpicon with all the sides. I left my plate as clean as it was before they served the food.
author: Al C.

description: Oye Managua is out go-to restaurant for Nicaraguan food. I've had many parties at home with food from Oye. We order several of the Maria Elena platter which feeds 3 people. Done. The service can be a bit slow but always courteous and friendly. The Nicaraguan beer is fantastic. Nice Nica ambiance. Love this place!
author: Maria P.

description:
If I still lived near Bernal, I'd be here all the time.  It's like a dive bar, but a restaurant.  Everyone is very welcoming and you feel right at home.  Our server was the sweetest older gentleman -- I just wanted to hug him!

There are only a few obvious veggie dishes, but I bet you could ask them to pull together a big plate of sides and it would be awesome (I plan to do that next time).  I really enjoyed the plantain & cheese empanada, but was under the impression it would come with the rice/beans/maduros/queso that the other dinners did.  Still, it was enough for a meal.

We also really liked the live music.  Dude has a great voice, and his selection of 80's ballads in Spanish and English was oddly soothing.  I'd totally come here just to listen to him and have a few too many beers.
author: Andi T.

description: My husband and i are huge fans of carribean food, so when he suggested this place i was excited! When we first walked in, a whole bunch of people (including the waitresses) just stared at us. It was an awkward situation. We weren't greeted and didn't know if we were supposed to wait to be seated or seat ourselves. After a couple minutes of just standing there, we decided to just seat ourselves. A few more minutes passed before one of the waitresses came by and gave us a couple menus. The lady who ended up being our server (who also happened to be one of the ones that was staring at us earlier) ended up being nice to us the rest of our time there. I'm guessing it's because she wanted to make sure she got a good tip. The food was pretty good and you get a pretty good portion for the price you pay. We'll probably try a few more restaurants before deciding if we want to come back though..
author: Mertani G.

description: Came here for lunch - service was fine, foods was good (i have to admit I have had a little better in the area) but I would definitely come back and would recommend to friends as well.  Atmosphere was casual - there was a game on that day so lots of Niner fans watching the TV's and grubbing on some yummy Nicarguan food.
author: Rachael C.

description: Delicious food, huge portion! Loved the breaded chicken dish I had and everything that came with it. We will be back! My husband is Nicaraguan and loves to get his fix once in awhile! I am now a fan too!
author: Nancy C.

description: Since I have been to Nicaragua I can say this place makes pretty good food. It is small and can get really crowded, but it is always a fun place to eat and chill.
author: C W.

description:
the place is nice, i love their chancho con yuca. is as good as it can be. 

bought a nicaragua jersey there from www.pinolero.net i saw they had them on their website too.  good ass nicoya place
author: Jorge O.

description: Can't go wrong with gallo pinto. They were good cooks when it was the red balloon. Been there twice now & was disappointed. Last week i ordered sopa de queso...not good not good at all. Threw it away. The rice was good. I'm trying to find a good Nicaraguense restaurant since La Carne Asada left. Eddy you could have run the place!!
author: Dee G.

description: The food was delicious reason why I'm giving 4 stars, the cacao omagh delicious,  but the service was 2 out 5.I felt like if I was at someone's house trying to be liked. Also, it's helpful if you have a sign that says, "wait to be seated," that way people don't look stupid standing and being looked at by other sitting down. Happy Easter!
author: Roxx P.

description: Found this by accident...what luck!  The food was really tasty.  The portions were large enough to share, even with my three children (ages 3, 6, and 9).  Although there was a slight language barrier, the wait staff was friendly and very attentive.  I will be taking my husband back with us the next time we go!
author: Joelle P.

description: I can see why reviews are so wishy washy. I went to this place years ago and it was alright. I recently went and I'm happy to say that it was really good! I had the Salpicon and it was fresh. They serve a good amount of beans and rice. Another occasion, I had the Vigoron. No complaints again. I'm coming back to you with open arms, my fellow Nicoyas, because I've been satisfied with your food for the past three times I been there in a month.
author: Miss P.

description:
Muy bueno, muy rico, y muy sabroso!

I had a really good time here when I went. There was excellent live music and I loved it. So did my bday date that happends to be half Mex/Nicoya. We danced in the very small dancing area to Live Latino music. 

The food is out of this world. Most people confuse Nicaraugense food for the ideal Mexican food and expect spicy salsa and burritos but its way different. I enjoyed the Queso Frito(fried cheese), gallo pinto(mixture of black beans and rice), and of course the chancho. Everything is cooked with more sweet than spicy and that makes the difference between Nicaragua food and Mexican food. I did love the special drinks that they make here as well. 

Think out of the box and try this place. It may take a little bit of getting used to it at first but than its something that hits all of your taste buds for sure.
author: California R.

description:
I love Oye Managua.......

The owner of this fine establishment was the owner of the Red Balloon so when he got a new restaurant I had to follow. Not only does Oye Managua have one of the best cooks the food speaks for itself. I live in NYC but this is the one of the 1st places I come to when I touch down in San Francisco and it is what I bring on the plane with me. 

Everything on the menu is delicious my favorite is the gallo pinto con crema.... 

This is a family run business who know what they are doing....

If you are ever in the Bay Area make sure you stop by and give them a try... Keep in mind they are closed on Mondays & I believe Tuesday I could be wrong so call ahead.........
author: Ibedatnica I.

description:
I 've been here a couple times after desperately looking for a Nicaraguan restaurant, I finally decided to go there with my peruvian boyfriend that thinks only peruvian food is good stuff.
We order the Maria Elena plate and it was full of my favorites, queso frito and platano verde, OMG i miss that so much, so I go there every time I can.
The service is very friendly and the staff reminds me the Nicaraguan accent as they speak.
Food is very good but small portions heehee...
The cacao is the deal!!!!
author: Kris S.

description: Food is incredible! Went there for a wedding rehearsal dinner and it was the best Nicaraguan food I have ever had. The owners are very accommodating as well and made us all feel like family. Thank you again for making my best friends special day memorable!
author: Robert A.

description:
This place is the so bad on hospitality horrible .. If I could rate it 0 stars I would I went out to dinner with my one year old daughter . First of all while you wait they don't give you chips n salsa . But after all the when I am getting ready to order the waitress looked miserable , no smile  , just bad but let's over pass the . She takes my order then when she brings me the food she brings me only one napkin , so I asked her for more napkins then I was waiting for my tortillas n she never brought them so I had to ask her . Don't the food come with tortillas she was like yeah . So I want them . Then she brings them . Now let's get to the worst part I am done eating and I tell her can you put this to go please she says yeah . She comes back with the f.... Plate for me to do it on my own . Wtf .. I was so pissed I asked for the owner then I tell the owner  what kind if restaurant is this . She going to tell my I am sorry it's a health law when we can't do it our selves . All this other bullahit n then she said yeah you do have the option to have her do it for you . So sorry . I am sorry  *. I told her just let me pay. So I can get out if here . 
I don't recommended think about twice .
author: Mayra L.

description: One of the best restaurant in the city! They have big plate called The Especial Maria Elena OMG its the bomb... If ever in the city and looking to eat Nicaraguense food i recommend this place... Decent prices very lovely place.. Great customer service...
author: Bianca O.

description:
I took my kids here to experience a little of the great food that their dad grew up eating. I am so amazed that the place is packed with people at 3:00 in the afternoon. We started with the Vigaron and it is deli-sh. It was a mountain of delicious cabbage, tomato and tons of porky goodness which my kids loved and at the very bottom is a creamy yuka. Yum! 

The nacatamales was sooo good that my husbands eyes literally rolled over his head. My kids had the fried chancho and they loved it especially the sweet maduro. 

I recommend this place and I cannot wait to try everything on their menu. BTW on weekends they have the most amazing mondango soup.
author: Rhodora E.

description: Ate here for the first time. After waiting 10 minutes for the hostess to acknowledge us we saw that she was also the only waitress here. We were seated too close to the bar area and nothing worse than a bunch of buzzed loud mouth Latinos hovering in the dining area. After waiting another 20 minutes for our food it got louder and as good as the food could have been; the ambience ruined this experience. Very small place, too warm, no air flow until someone opens the front door. If you try this place the food wasn't that bad, but get a seat near the exit.
author: Robert L.

description:
This past Sunday the family and I ate at Oye Managua at 30th and Mission in the city. Mmm mmmm mmmmm! It's not like I don't eat Nicaraguan food on a regular basis but sometimes it's nice to give mom a break from the kitchen.

Upon arrival, I found the decor to be rather random and amusing (read: sea life on the walls). But it did feel like being in Nicaragua with the fact that everyone in there was Nicaraguense and the way the tables were set - plastic over the table cloths, serrated knives, place mats, etc. It was like home!

When I opened the menu, I squealed! They had some of my fave dishes like mondongo and nacatamales. What is mondongo you ask? It's a bowl of awesomeness. It's a very flavorful soup with tripe, tendon, yucca, veggies and of course, the slice of corn cob. I hadn't had mondongo in a looooong time because no one wants to make it. You bet I ordered it!

My aunt ordered the nacatamal (think giant tamale, but WAY better) which was excellent.

[Tangent on why nacatamales are better than tamales....nacatamales are 1) larger than a regular, Mexican or even Salvadorean style tamale 2) there's more going on inside: achiote marinated pork, rice, olive, raisin, a little potato, slice of tomato and a giant chunk of pork fat to keep it all moist. 3) Since they are steamed in plantain leaf, the masa is everso moist...and yes, the pork fat helps too. A completely satisfying meal in one package!]

My mom ordered the special which was Bajo (or vaho) which is meat cooked with yucca and green plantains in plantain leaves...SO good! It can be eaten with rice and the typical cabbage slaw of Nicaraguan cuisine. My dad ordered the grilled pork plate which came with rice, slaw and queso frito.

We also started with an order of tajadas, fried green plantains, and of course the queso frito. Don't be scared of the fried cheese, there are much "scarier" items in American food. It's a hard cheese that is fried...salty and delicious.

The staff was fun and it felt very comfortable being there although I'm sure some of the folks were like, "Where did you people come from?!"

Nicaragua is a very diverse place!
author: Karla F.

description: I have been here so many times and the food is just amazing. I normally go on Sundays and listen to the Dario, the music performer who is there in Sundays. It's such a great atmosphere. The food kicks butt. I always get the Maria Elena special it's so huge! One if their best items on the menu. I suggest to order that. One of the best Nicaraguan restaurants in the mission.
author: Food C.

description:
This place is excellent.  I went on a Saturday afternoon and it was was very popular.  I had the Pollo Asado (roasted quarter chicken).  It was amazingly moist and came with maduro, which is fried ripe plantain, rice, beans, and a salad.

The place has a very casual atmosphere, the staff were very friendly, and there was even live music.  The walls are painted with gigantic seascapes that makes you feel like you're in an aquarium.  Very quirky but I liked it.

I totally recommend this place.  Good food and a fun place. BTW: I noticed that the staff were happy to accommodate a large group (10-12 people) who came in while I was there.
author: Kevin C.

description: Ehhh, Its a grease pit. Everything was glistening in oil. They try to charge on gallo pinto (rice and beans), a nicaraguan staple. They are open late.  Flavor-wise its whatever I wouldve been equally satisfied if not more going to an In n Out and my wallet wouldve been happy too.
author: R C.

description: I love Oye! Managua!!! Being from Nicaragua, I have to say it's my favorite restaurant in SF for Nicaraguan food. The best is for breakfast having gallopinto, nacatamales, huevos revueltos con pan, and cacao. It's the ultimate cure for hangovers. For lunch, definitely the vigoron, carne desmenusada, or the caballo bayo with tonas.  It feels like your in Managua and eating at home, I think the owner is Elena who makes you feel at home, everyone is loud, listening to fun music, and having a good time. It's nice to see little Nicaraguan restaurants in a huge sea of Mexican ones.
author: Stephanie M.

description: the food was ok.. I ordered pollo asado and it wasn't a big deal, I mean it was fine but it wasn't worth it for the wait. My family reserved the place and they were't ready for us. we waited for someone to took our order about 45 minutes, and more than 2 hours to get the food. the worst part about the wait was when they finally gave us the drinks one of the stupid waitres spill the drink on my grandfather and she didn't even say sorry. and also during the wait my family and I decided to take some pictures and this same waitres was so mean with us because we were on her way. it also happened that my cousins where playing with their smart phones while they were waiting and a random kid startes trying to play with them and he wouldn't live them alone; the kid was the son of someone who work at the restaurant. just saying, if you want food from nicaragua the TINAJAS is way better. I defenitly don't recomend this place to anyone... and for the record I gave the 1 star because I couldn't write the review without giving them any.
author: Jenny A.

description: Came here today waitress was cool accommodated us with free drinks and a free bracelet that says Nicaragua. Had the chicken today and it was DELICIOUS, the meat literally came off the bone. Ill be back!
author: Marvin C.

description: Oye Managua has great Nicaraguense Food but I hate the fact that they have not fixed that dam Visa/ATM debit machine. So if you want to eat there you have to make sure that you bring cash with you. I know this seem dumb, but my goodness this should not take 1 year to fixed. I've been going there to eat for the last year and Half and this dam machine still not working. I think they do it so that they don't have to pay to much taxes and not reporting the true amount of what they actually make. we are in United States of America, Not Nicaragua....so there should not be a reason why they have not fixed this machine.
author: W P.

description: Oye! Managua...all I really want to say is "CACAO"! Only cause it sounds sooo cool to say...It was also a delicious drink. Went there the day before Cinco De Mayo so they had a singer.  The service was really friendly and I thought it was cool the waitress automatically assumed I was latina and started speaking in spanish. I had just finished studying restaurant etiquette in my Espanol class so I was able to use it. WOOHOO, thank you CCSF! Anyways my friend had the Camarones Rancheros and I ordered the Especial Maria Elena. My friend dish came with a Nica sauce that was delicious, but this dish may get a little messy as the skins are still on the camarones. The Especial Maria Elena was more than I bargained for, granted I was 8 months pregnant. I took half of my dish home. The food was very filling and tasty. I've tried other Nicaraguan Restaurants and these dishes were not only better, but fresher looking.  The only thing is the price, it was a bit more then most restaurants.  Bonus, they also have a jukebox.
author: Zara-Maria S.

description: Deliciso! Authentic Nicaraguan food, most weekends they have live music too, fun.
author: Mrs. L.

description:
My father came to America from Nicaragua when he was 14. Growing up we didn't know much about "the Old Country," as he would call it, other than some of his childhood stories that usually ended up with him setting fire to something or getting severely punished by a nun (thanks for sending ME to Catholic school too, Dad.) As the self appointed cook of our family, my Dad would take a freestyle approach to cooking often not knowing what the final product would be. He fancied himself the Charlie Parker of the kitchen and believed that recipes were for people who didn't know what they were doing. More often than not, the end result had some sort of meat with a flour thickened sauce from the cast iron pan he would cook EVERYTHING in. Needless to say, my exposure to Nicaraguan cuisine was diluted by his "creativity." He did make some kick ass fried plantains though.

I pass Oye! Managua, a Nicaraguan restaurant, everyday on my way to work and decided that I should probably have some idea of what actual Nicaraguan food is. As I expected, we were the only non-Latinos in the place. That's cool. I'd be disturbed if the place was full of Chinese people.

Well the waitress came over and started speaking Spanish to us. This was an excellent opportunity to impress my wife with my command of the Spanish language. Actually, my Spanish is best suited for making stupid jokes and insulting peoples' mothers but I muddled through. At one point she asked if I wanted a mix of mature and green plantains. Either that, or she asked if I wanted to be spanked with a piece of raw liver. In either case, the answer was an emphatic, "Si!"

The food arrived (sans spanking) and it was actually very similar to Salvadorean food. Most plates came with black beans, rice, and a cabbage slaw and EVERY plate had fried plantains on it. It was all very good and everything had a home-cooked feel to it. A strange familiarity came over me and I felt a slight connection to the food and my heritage. It was very cool.

You don't have to be Latino or even Nicaraguan to eat at Oye! Managua and I'm sure anyone can appreciate its homespun style of cooking. Next time I'm having the liver.
author: Josua P.

description:
This place is kitschy!  Blue dolphins painted all over the walls and the ceilings, a guy playing the keyboards and singing Nicaraguan songs, and random pumpkin lights all over the walls.

The food - Nicaraguan - I tried the Seven Seas Soup, which was a real pain in the ass because I had to crack the crab and lobster with my bare hands.  Also checked out the Baho con Arroz - basically brisket - the meat was pretty good, though the yucca and plantains were terrible!

Be sure to try the cacao drink.  Awesome.
author: Gabriel D.

description: Great Nica food!!!! Staff is nice!! If you have not tried yet your really missing out
author: Felix E.

description:
NICOYA WOOT WOOT!!!

I love this place, I seriously feel like I'm in a restaurant in Nicaragua, The food is good but not a generous/better than las Las tinajas!!! Toñas and Victorias are nice and cold!!! =), the owner is very nice, they have really good service... Once in a while they have a live band that is really awesome! and the Juke box is pretty cool.... This place really makes me feel at home! haha. Ohhh their Cacao is really good too!!!!. 

I would definitely recommend this place!
author: Diana M.

description: The food is really good, but the place needs a facelift. I have to be in the mood for a dive setting to go there. Maybe if you've already had a couple beers first. It's worth it, though, cuz the food is so damn good.
author: Shirley M.

description:
The food here was good, but the service needs improvement. The music was way too loud even after I requested for it to be lowered. I had to ask multiple times for utensils, and my order was mixed-up.

The one saving grace, the food was good.
author: Fabian M.

description:
This is another one of my favorite Nicaraguan restaurants, the draw back(reason of the 4 star) is that there is no parking, if you park at Safeway you risk your car being towed. .
If im in the City after working hours or on the weekend this is the place to go, they have a one guy band(he plays the organ, has a drum machine and sings pretty good).
I had carne asada con gallo pinto y queso frito...yummy, Cacao is my favorite drink and it is delicious, the last time I was there I ordered Nacatamales which are humongous and they tast great.
I like to take my family there as is safe and the people there are usually friendly.
Also the price is good but no Flor de Cana...too bad
author: Rich M.

description:
NICOYAS IN THE HOUSE!!
Ok, so me and wifey just ate here. I was craving "mi comida de mi terra".
Today is friday.
 So we met there right after she got off  work, around 6pm. Parking here is a pain but if you ghetto like me you just park in the Safeway across the street. You can circle around I'm sure you will find a meter spot. 
Ok so we get in, plenty of tables just 3 other customers eating. When were leaving two more couples were coming in.
So I order the carne asada plate it comes with gallo pinto, maduros, queso frito and nica salad. My wife got the pollo asado with the rice and beans. She is very picky so if the food was bad I would have heard it.
I heard nothing, She like it. 
My plate was also good, I would have like it if my food was warmer. It wasn't cold but not hot. 
I went with the cacao drink. You have to try it. Alot of yelpers would agree. 
Prices are decent. They also cater which I might try. We nicas party. 
The only setback is the decor. Your traditional Latin/Mexican joint with paintings of everything and dey mama. This place went with underwater theme, of course Xmas lights everywhere. My eyes hurt, but my stomach is full.  
They get 4 stars 1 minus because of the decor. Im out............
author: Y r.

description:
I just ate here last week and it was the 3rd time that I have been to this restaurant. I absolutely love the food here and the friendliness of the staff is excellent!

I usually come here with my girlfriend who is Nicaraguense, and we get a mix of everything....Things like Gallo Pinto, Queso Frito, and of course the always yummy Maduros (Plantains).  The food is so flavorful and you could literally close your eyes and point to the menu and you will get something very tasty.

To drink, I would recommend getting the Cacao. If you haven't had this before, you should try it. It's like a Cinnamon, vanilla bean, drink served on ice.
author: Brian C.

description:
This is the second time I've had Nicaraguan food in a restaurant in the city.  Las Tinajas was the first.  The charm of this place is really vastly underrated with the sailing motif...wait, "coastal motif" that is very apparent inside.  The murals are on the walls and ceilings, but who doesn't want to feel like they're in a submarine once in a while?  Besides that, Paola and I had separate plates of food, but in a very traditional style, we both got rice, plantains, squeaky fried cheese, and beans.  I got the bistek empanizado (breaded steak), while Paola got the indio viejo (sp??)---this was a bit on the salty side, but still full of flavor, with big pieces of mint infused.  We both got cacau to drink---thick with cinnamon :)
It's worth the trip out to 30th and Mission, but I understand why it can be overlooked.  
Plenty of seats for big groups and the food came very quickly.
author: felix c.

description:
Loved the "Gran Provencial" for $25, which has lots of steak, chicken, plantains, yucca, beans and rice, and Nicuraguan cole slaw. It's plenty, and you should split it with a friend. Everything is very authentic (according to my Nicuraguan friends).

The drinks here are really authentic and delicious. One is called "Cacao" and is $3 and is really delicious. I forget the names of the other drinks, but they are all sweet -- one is corn-based and one barley-based.
author: Adam Z.

description:
As I was eating here this evening I mentally tallied stars:
"One for the clean, latin atmosphere and live entertainment."
"One for the fast and friendly service.
"One for the BEST carne asada I've ever had."
"One for plantains, fried cheese, rice, beans and salad on the side."
"One for ice cold cheap Nicaraguan beer."
I spoke my revelation aloud: "Guys, this place gets 5 stars."
author: Eric S.

description:
Esta Mierda Esta de Acachimba!
BUT yeah. Love it. Know the owner
she is cool. She previously owned Red Balloons over between 24th and 23rd and Mission but sold it to only make a better and improve version of it and its called Oye Managua! is good food but. downside (for me at least) is the portion is small...I'm a big fella so I can be wrong but over all pretty damn close to food in Managua, Nicaragua. Da Motherland for me.
author: Nelson F.

description:
Last Saturday we had a college graduation party for my daughter.  What to serve, what to serve?  Cousin raved about Oye!  So rather than doing a Taco Bar (like everyone is doing these days) I decided to pay Oye! a visit and talked to one of the owners, Maria Elena.

What a sweet woman! Being 100% Nicaraguense and having grown up on Nica food all my life I knew exactly what I wanted for the party.  So Maria Elena worked with me on the menu.  I ordered Carne Desmenusada (shredded beef), Pollo Asado (grill chicken) with a jalapeño sauce, not terribly spicy but oh so delicious, Maduros Frito (fried sweet plantains), Platano Frito (plantain chips), Queso Frito (fried cheese), Ensalada de Repollo (cabbage salad), Gallo Pinto (rice & beans), and tortillas.

My guests consisted of Nicaraguenses & Gringos.  The Nicas were in heaven with everything we served.  The Gringos were in ecstasy, some serving themselves twice.  The Carne Desmenusda & the Pollo Asado were such a HIT!!  Everything was absolutely Delicious!!!!

I ordered for 50 people, although I had 65 guests and had leftovers for my family (thank goodness).  All this food for under $500, definitely a lot cheaper than the Taco Bar.  Not to mention that she had a few of the guys help load all of this into my car.  

I am a real foodie and since Nica food is my comfort food and my mother doesn't cook Nicaraguense food anymore I often visit another Nica restaurant whenever in the city.  This will now definitely be my new stop!!
author: El L.

description:
the Grilled chicken in Jalapeno sauce is off the hook. It's better than the one I had in Masaya, Nicaragua. The sauce has more kick and the grilled chicken is tender. 

The grilled steak on the other was mediocre but it goes well with their picante sauce. 

The Cacao drink  and Cayolitas drink were pretty good.
author: Hebert J.

description:
I love going to Oye Managua.  Especially when we come visit Pops.  I love their gallo pinto.  It has the right consistency.  Kinda crunchy but fluffy.  I hate when the rice in the gallo pinto is sticky or mushy.  Not a problem here.  The cacao is great!  It reminds me of how my grandma use to make it with the molinio (sp).  Also, we always ask for our tajadas sliced extra thin and they always come through.

Service could be better.  But that seems to be the theme with my "peoples".  It seems that service is slow in any Central American restaurant.
author: Karla B.

description:
This place is home cooking all the way!

In preparation for an upcoming trip to Central America, The Hubs and I went here for late lunch. Aside from us, the only other people in the resto was a group of older men arguing and debating with each other -- which just added to the genuine feeling of this place. It reminded me of being in the Phlippines and having all the 'manongs' sitting around talking shit. :)

I had the oxtail soup (which isn't as adventurous as it seems -- Filipinos use that cut of meat a lot so I've had it at my grandma's) which came with plaintains, rice and cabbage slaw. I loved everything about my dish. Flavorfull, as homecooked as you can get. The Hubs got the fried pork with the fried plantains and the fried cheese. (When it comes to food, he doesn't care about calories -- lucky him!) I had a bite. SO good. 

I can't wait to go back and try other dishes on the menu!
author: joann p.

description: This is the closest thing I can find to my family's cooking in San Francisco. LOVE. LOVE. LOVE.
author: nicole l.

description: Probably the most authentic Nicaraguan you can get on the west coast of the US. The decor is kitschy, and you might think twice about going in, but I recommend it: The food is very, very authentic. I had the chancho asado with gallo pinto, queso frito, ensalada, y tajadas maduras (charbroiled & seasoned pork cutlet, rice and bean blend, fried cheese, salad, and fried ripe plantains) with cacao (like horchata, but better) to drink . All the servers were friendly, including the host. We got there early (~ 6:00pm) tonight (Friday), and it was nearly empty, but within 1/2 hour, the place was nearly full. I was pleased to see a variety of folks there, from the "abuelas y doñas" to "gringos". The portions are rather large, so bring an appetite and forget your diet at home. Fine food at a Fair Price.. my friend and I ate for about $15 each including drink.
author: clark i.

description: the best NACATAMAL. capers,onions,potato,rice,yerba buena(mint),raisons,etc.etc. NOBODY on this planet can make A tamale like the NICARAGUENSE do. That is why it's not called a tamale. It is called A NACATAMALE. The nicaraguans also can run circles around the menudo soup.  Nicaraguans call it MONDONGO. The Nicaraguans also enrich the sopup  with everything in the book..  Aparently nicaraguans do it better. If you can't handle it eat corn.
author: OSEPH E.

description:
My friends are regs to this place and wanted me to try good Nicaraguan food. We all had the carne asada plates. It comes with plantains, gallo pinto, fried cheese. I thought the fried cheese was going to be hella good , but it was a little chewy. I imagined a fried piece of cheese to be crispy on the outside and soft and melty in the middle. 
The steak was okay and the plantains had no flavor.  I was expecting it to be a little sweeter. The best part of the meal was the gallo pinto.  I love this stuff.  Its just rice and beans, but it tastes so good.  Maybe its the way they cook it.  Gallo pinto is Nicaraguan fried rice I suppose.
I was going to give this 3.5 stars, but I had to bring it down to 3 stars because of the service.  The guy that was serving us, we call him Grandpa cause he just looks it, he forgot a lot of stuff.  My friend Jorge was like watch this he's going to forget my sprite.  What do you know he did.  Then we asked for the bill.  Jorge said watch this, he's going to forget our bill the next time he comes out.  And guess what happened, he forgot the next three times he came out.  We had a good laugh about it, I can't stay mad at Grandpa.
author: Henrick R.

description:
I really enjoyed my experience at this place. I trusted my friend Huevos with this recommendation since he's nicaraguan and I have never had nicaraguan food. The Nacatamale is AMAZING to say the least. It was $5 and very filling and even came with a toasted Iron King Bread. The Brisket was also pretty good and the Plantain was AWESOME. I also love the Yucca too. In terms of the drink I loved the Cacao so much that I had to order two. I didn't even mind paying extra for another one since there was no free refill. 
The only reason why this place was not a perfect 5 stars was because the service was pretty slow. It took quite a while to get food though the owner and the workers were really nice. I definitely want to come back to this place again.
author: Nir B.

description: Love this place. This is real Nicaraguan food. It's just like eating at home. I've tried other Nicaraguan restaurants and I will never go back to them. This place does give good service, and portions are good. My favorite is the maduro and ceso frito. 8)~ YUUUMMM!!!! ....Nacatamales ARE WAY BETTER than MEXICAN TAMALES.
author: S C.

description: The food is as good as the corner Fritangas' back in the homeland. El vigoron, el indio viejo and like everyone else commented the Nacatamales. Enjoy every thing with a Toña in your hand and you'll be transported to the land of lakes and volcanoes, and really amazing food.
author: Lester L.

description: Outstanding meal at oye managua today!!! The especial maria elena was delicious...carne asada, chancho asado, queso frito, gallo pinto, ensalada y una cervecita nicoya...toña!!! ay que rico!!
author: Bane V.

description: This place is really really good.  Its like soul food-Nicoya style.  Its the kinda food where you feel like your in a coma after because there was so much and it was so good-kinda like Thanksgiving dinner.  I had the nacatamale thinking it would be just like a regular tamale-no no no.  This was like a tamale on hormones-the thing basically had all the contents of a full meal stuffed in it, I could barely eat half of it.  My boyfriend had some kinda steak dish that was really good and his mom had the chicken soup which was delicious.  And the sides are soooo good, fried plantains and fried cheese.  Definitely not diet food, so if your watching what you eat, go somewhere else.
author: Renee S.

description: I liked this restaurant.  We ordered corn drink (you must try it) as well as breaded beef and charbroiled chicken.  They were both very good. Service was very good.
author: vadim m.

description: Great place, super-friendly service, and they even gave me a sample of the coyolito drink, just because I asked what it was. We had the chancho with plantains & fried cheese, and the same with yucca and cabbage, and it was delicious. We mistakenly ordered a nacatamal as an appetizer, and ended up having 3 mains. Desserts sounded most interesting, but we'd eaten too much already. Definitely going back.
author: Chris K.

description: Worst food I've ever had in my life and worse service. I can't even believe that some people would actually rate this as good food. I've had better food than this before. Waste of my Money and way to over priced for crap.
author: Ana H.

description: This place exceeded my expectations, I have never tried Nicaraguan food before so I do not know if this is 100% authentic, but Oye! Managua was delicious. The decor is a bit cheesy but you will complelety forget yoy surroundings once you dig in, I ordered the chicken with fried cheese, beans, plantains and a salad. It is a LOT of food so go when you are really hungry and can stuff your face.
author: Sadie L.

description:
Brother in law brought us here. He's all kinds of nicoya mixed with russian jews, and who knows what else. But he had been coming here since he was a child... or at least had know the owner since then. Three stars for a few reasons. 

1. The giant painted killer whales on the ceiling. No idea, but I like them. 
2. The fact that some one decided to write Nemo on the paintings of clown fish on the bathroom 
3. The scary ass lady at the bar, who was either giving the evil eye, the a very drunk come hither eye. Either way, it kind of ruined my meal. 
4. The meal itself wasn't all that bad. Large portions, but my carne asada was well done, and they didn't give me an option... eating meat well done... well there really isn't any reason to eat meat if it's well done. You might as well become a vegetarian. 
5. White people walked in. For being such a mom and pop kinda place I wouldn't really expect to see them here. but then again I have been known to show up to michelin star restaurants.
6. Live, kinda cheesy, keyboard playing musicians. I actually liked it. I liked it a lot more than having mariachi bands singing to you in taquerias and restaurants.
7. I like it, but I wouldn't come here again on my own. It would have to be suggested by the brother in-;aw or his family fam.
author: danny e.

description: Love this place...NOT the decor but the food makes up for the tacky deco. There cacao drink is the best. (Cacao is like horchata but better because it has a stong choocolate flavor). I usually get the combination plate which has grilled jumbo shrimp, white rice, black beans, cabbage salad, and the fried cheese...love that fried cheese. I also like their salpicon dish. All the dishes I have tried have been very tasty.
author: Karen T.

description: I really enjoyed the  food and the atmosphere at this place.  The atmosphere was like a Nicaraguan social club.  Everyone seemed to know everyone, but newcomers are welcome.  This was my first try at Nicaraguan food and I loved it. I'm not a big fan of plantains and I even like those.
author: Robert O.

description: Went there for a girlfriend's b-day on a Saturday evening with a large group.  The food was phenomenal!  I think we ordered the majority of plates on the menu and they were each fantastic!  There was live music which really added to the ambiance ....alegre!
author: Monica B.

description: As part of a homework project to try Nicaraguan food, we came here with 13 year olds and we weren't sure what to expect.  We ended up having a fantastic evening. We arrived at 5 on a Sunday night, and the place was packed!  We had to wait a bit for our table, but the waiter could not have been nicer.  We had drinks while we waited and looked over the menu.  Once we were seated, we ordered family style, and shared the platters (portions are WAY generous), including the special, a delicious Valencia rice (like a Nicaraguan paella).  During our several hours there, we were entertained by a mariachi band, a keyboardist/singer, and a duet.  The crowd is there for music, so if you are there to talk or chat, you're in the wrong place.  Several men at the table next to ours got up to dance, and my 13 year old son joined them.  They could not have been more welcoming, or gracious.  Oye Managua is a very local, authentic, family friendly restaurant, and I'd recommend it to anyone curious about Nicaraguan cuisine or culture.
author: Christine H.

description: I Love this place! My first time here and having Nicaraguense food! The food is so good and the people here are so sweet! I enjoyed the Live music too :) Very fun times!
author: Johana R.

description: We ate there after work one day last week and the food was so awesome we asked them to cater our housewarming party this weekend.  It was a major hit.  We got the Indio Viejo, Pollo Asada, and Nacatomales, Pinto de Gallo, plaintains and fried cheese.  We plan to go back, again and again and again.
author: Aurora H.

description: Went here for the first time last night and we loved it!  The food was really good and the service was amazing.  Christopher was our server and we thought he was incredibly helpful and fun.  My the time we were done with our meal, we felt as if we had become friends and family with everyone there.  It was a really great experience.  I recommend you try it.
author: sonya g.

description: I went here on a fluke. I am a BIG fan of Red Balon so for Nicoya food I normally go there or Las Tinajas(if they are open). I ordered a Nac and my nephew ordered the carne encebollada. Our food was brought to us right away! This was definitely a first for this type of restaurant. I was prepared to have to wait a while, but this was not the case. The taste of the food was excellent. The beans were so good! My Nac was delicious! The prices were not bad either, the place is clean and good music was playing too. I am definitely going back.
author: Carmen T.

description: This place is about 20 feet from my door! Been here twice now and its so cute. I love the ocean theme and the crowd. At nighttime they have a dude who plays keyboards and sings his heart out. The first time I got the Camarones Rancheros and they were delicious--HUGE shrimps that you have to dismember to put inside your mouth along with rice and beans and a side salad. Today I went for lunch and I got huevos with gallo pinto with a side of ripe plantains, and boyfriend got the chicken and albondigas soup. The huevos and gallo pinto were only $6 which is a steal and very filling. They put onions and peppers in the eggs but served no hot sauce. The plantains came with fried cheese, their specialty. It sat nicely in my tummy and didn't weigh me down and the price was RIGHT. The broth of the soup, especially with rice in it, was comforting and very savory. I have no plans to cut this place outta my life.
author: Laura M.

description: The food here always reminds me of my grandma. She could cook way better ofcourse, but they try. The cacao is excellent, and nothing beats there steak with onions plate. They serve up big portions so come here hungry, cuz you'll leave full!
author: Sleep E.

description: I've never had Nicaraguan food before. I can barely even say 'Nicaraguan' w/out repeating it again.  Anyway onto my review.   It looks like the owner commissioned my 9 yr old nephew to paint the walls (and ceiling) with scenes from Disney's Little Mermaid on it.  And the "professional" paintings lit w/ special lamps were beyond tacky.  The service was SLOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOW.  From taking the orders to getting something down on our table was painfully slow.  BUT, when the food finally arrived and I took my first bite, I forgot all about the long wait.  The naca tamale was nothing like mexican tamales, which I don't really care for.  The naca tamale was really tender, flavorful from the spices, sausage, veggies, etc.   DA BOMB.   Not to mention it was $5 and huge...i would approximate it to weight 3lbs.  The fried plantains were really good too.  Despite the bad service, I'd come here again!
author: LT B.

description: Was in town visiting and thought I'd hit up a local Nicaraguan restaurant that got great reveiws here on Yelp. I am extremely disappointed in the service and the food. When we got there, we waited for about 15 minutes before the waiter even came to take our drink order. We ordered water and got a pitcher of water for our table to pour ourselves. Sitting right on top of the water was a yellow piece of....something, I don't know what, but it was gross. How did the waiter not see it?? Sorry, but we weren't going to drink that. Then we ordered our food. The serving sizes were large, but the food was about the worst I've ever tasted. The steak was extremely bland. The gallo pinto was hard...probably refried...and then refried again and again and again. Pretty much everything that our whole party ordered was tasteless and bland. After we were done eating, we had to wait another 15 minutes or so (keep in mind, the restaurant was empty) for the waiter to come back to our table for us to even ask for the check. With 5 entrees ordered, our total came to a little over $100. Definitely will never go back to this place when I'm in town. I'll stick to my favorite Nicaraguan restaurant in Los Angeles instead.
author: Kam S.
